title: Hello
content: Welcome to W. W. Norton & Company's style guidelines This is where all our guidelines documenations across different languages will live. This is a work in progress.

title: W. W. Norton Configsâ€‹
content: Our configs are customized to align with our style guides. Style guides and linting configs for code at Norton eslint-config-nortonstylelint-config-nortonprettier-config-norton

title: Rule declarationâ€‹
content: A â€œrule declarationâ€ is the name given to a selector (or a group of selectors) with an accompanying group of properties. Here's an example: .listing { font-size: 18px; line-height: 1.2; } Copy

title: Selectorsâ€‹
content: In a rule declaration, â€œselectorsâ€ are the bits that determine which elements in the DOM tree will be styled by the defined properties. Selectors can match HTML elements, as well as an element's class, ID, or any of its attributes. Here are some examples of selectors: .my-element-class { /* ... */ } [aria-hidden] { /* ... */ } Copy

title: Propertiesâ€‹
content: Finally, properties are what give the selected elements of a rule declaration their style. Properties are key-value pairs, and a rule declaration can contain one or more property declarations. Property declarations look like this: /* some selector */ { color: #333; background: #f1f1f1; } Copy Use em or rem for font-size: property valueâ€‹ W.W. Norton & Company strongly suggests using em or rem for font-size as opposed to px to ensure that font scaling works as expected accross devices. For all new projects, font sizes should be in em or rem.

title: Formattingâ€‹
content: Use tabs for indentation.Prefer dashes over camelCasing in class names. Underscores and PascalCasing are okay if you are using BEM (see OOCSS and BEM below). Do not use ID selectors.When using multiple selectors in a rule declaration, give each selector its own line.Put a space before the opening brace { in rule declarations.In properties, put a space after, but not before, the : character.Put closing braces } of rule declarations on a new line.Put blank lines between rule declarations. Bad .avatar { border: 2px solid white; border-radius: 50%; } .no, .nope, .not_good { // ... } #lol-no { // ... } Copy Good .avatar { border: 2px solid white; border-radius: 50%; } .one, .selector, .per-line { // ... } Copy

title: Commentsâ€‹
content: Prefer line comments (// in Sass-land) to block comments.Prefer comments on their own line. Avoid end-of-line comments.Write detailed comments for code that isn't self-documenting: Uses of z-indexCompatibility or browser-specific hacks

title: OOCSS and BEMâ€‹
content: We encourage some combination of OOCSS and BEM for these reasons: It helps create clear, strict relationships between CSS and HTMLIt helps us create reusable, composable componentsIt allows for less nesting and lower specificityIt helps in building scalable stylesheets OOCSS, or â€œObject Oriented CSSâ€, is an approach for writing CSS that encourages you to think about your stylesheets as a collection of â€œobjectsâ€: reusable, repeatable snippets that can be used independently throughout a website. Nicole Sullivan's OOCSS wikiSmashing Magazine's Introduction to OOCSS BEM, or â€œBlock-Element-Modifierâ€, is a naming convention for classes in HTML and CSS. It was originally developed by Yandex with large codebases and scalability in mind, and can serve as a solid set of guidelines for implementing OOCSS. CSS Trick's BEM 101Harry Roberts' introduction to BEM We recommend a variant of BEM with PascalCased â€œblocksâ€, which works particularly well when combined with components (e.g. React). Underscores and dashes are still used for modifiers and children. Example // ListingCard.jsx function ListingCard() { return ( <article class="ListingCard ListingCard--featured"> <h1 class="ListingCard__title">Adorable 2BR in the sunny Mission</h1> <div class="ListingCard__content"> <p>Vestibulum id ligula porta felis euismod semper.</p> </div> </article> ); } Copy /* ListingCard.css */ .ListingCard { } .ListingCard--featured { } .ListingCard__title { } .ListingCard__content { } Copy .ListingCard is the â€œblockâ€ and represents the higher-level component.ListingCard__title is an â€œelementâ€ and represents a descendant of .ListingCard that helps compose the block as a whole..ListingCard--featured is a â€œmodifierâ€ and represents a different state or variation on the .ListingCard block.

title: ID selectorsâ€‹
content: While it is possible to select elements by ID in CSS, it should generally be considered an anti-pattern. ID selectors introduce an unnecessarily high level of specificity to your rule declarations, and they are not reusable. For more on this subject, read CSS Wizardry's article on dealing with specificity.

title: JavaScript hooksâ€‹
content: Avoid binding to the same class in both your CSS and JavaScript. Conflating the two often leads to, at a minimum, time wasted during refactoring when a developer must cross-reference each class they are changing, and at its worst, developers being afraid to make changes for fear of breaking functionality. We recommend creating JavaScript-specific classes to bind to, prefixed with .js-: <button class="btn btn-primary js-request-to-book">Request to Book</button> Copy

title: Borderâ€‹
content: Use 0 instead of none to specify that a style has no border. Bad .foo { border: none; } Copy Good .foo { border: 0; } Copy

title: Syntaxâ€‹
content: Use the .scss syntax, never the original .sass syntaxOrder your regular CSS and @include declarations logically (see below)

title: Ordering of property declarationsâ€‹
content: W.W. Norton & Company's property ordering style is inspired by the order from GitHub's Primer design system instead of alphabetical. W.W. Norton also adds and groups accessibility properties to the bottom of that list. This list can be found on our Github repository. Property declarations List all standard property declarations, anything that isn't an @include or a nested selector. .btn-green { font-weight: bold; background: 'green'; // ... } Copy @include declarations Grouping @includes at the end makes it easier to read the entire selector. .btn-green { font-weight: bold; background: 'green'; @include transition(background 0.5s ease); // ... } Copy Nested selectors Nested selectors, if necessary, go last, and nothing goes after them. Add whitespace between your rule declarations and nested selectors, as well as between adjacent nested selectors. Apply the same guidelines as above to your nested selectors. .btn { font-weight: bold; background: 'green'; @include transition(background 0.5s ease); .icon { margin-right: 10px; } } Copy

title: Variablesâ€‹
content: Prefer dash-cased variable names (e.g. $my-variable) over camelCased or snake_cased variable names. It is acceptable to prefix variable names that are intended to be used only within the same file with an underscore (e.g. $_my-variable).

title: Mixinsâ€‹
content: Mixins should be used to DRY up your code, add clarity, or abstract complexity--in much the same way as well-named functions. Mixins that accept no arguments can be useful for this, but note that if you are not compressing your payload (e.g. gzip), this may contribute to unnecessary code duplication in the resulting styles.

title: Extend directiveâ€‹
content: @extend should be avoided because it has unintuitive and potentially dangerous behavior, especially when used with nested selectors. Even extending top-level placeholder selectors can cause problems if the order of selectors ends up changing later (e.g. if they are in other files and the order the files are loaded shifts). Gzipping should handle most of the savings you would have gained by using @extend, and you can DRY up your stylesheets nicely with mixins.

title: Nested selectorsâ€‹
content: Do not nest selectors more than three levels deep! .page-container { .content { .profile { // STOP! } } } Copy When selectors become this long, you're likely writing CSS that is: Strongly coupled to the HTML (fragile) â€”ORâ€”Overly specific (powerful) â€”ORâ€”Not reusable Again: never nest ID selectors! If you must use an ID selector in the first place (and you should really try not to), they should never be nested. If you find yourself doing this, you need to revisit your markup, or figure out why such strong specificity is needed. If you are writing well formed HTML and CSS, you should never need to do this.

title: Basic Rulesâ€‹
content: Only include one React component per file. However, multiple Stateless, or Pure, Components are allowed per file. eslint: react/no-multi-comp. Always use JSX syntax.Do not use React.createElement unless youâ€™re initializing the app from a file that is not JSX.react/forbid-prop-types will allow arrays and objects only if it is explicitly noted what array and object contains, using arrayOf, objectOf, or shape.

title: Class vs React.createClass vs statelessâ€‹
content: If you have internal state and/or refs, prefer class extends React.Component over React.createClass. eslint: react/prefer-es6-class react/prefer-stateless-function // bad const Listing = React.createClass({ // ... render() { return <div>{this.state.hello}</div>; } }); // good class Listing extends React.Component { // ... render() { return <div>{this.state.hello}</div>; } } Copy And if you donâ€™t have state or refs, prefer normal functions (not arrow functions) over classes: // bad class Listing extends React.Component { render() { return <div>{this.props.hello}</div>; } } // bad (relying on function name inference is discouraged) const Listing = ({ hello }) => ( <div>{hello}</div> ); // good function Listing({ hello }) { return <div>{hello}</div>; } Copy

title: Mixinsâ€‹
content: Do not use mixins. Why? Mixins introduce implicit dependencies, cause name clashes, and cause snowballing complexity. Most use cases for mixins can be accomplished in better ways via components, higher-order components, or utility modules.

title: Namingâ€‹
content: Extensions: Use .jsx extension for React components. eslint: react/jsx-filename-extension Filename: Use PascalCase for filenames. E.g., ReservationCard.jsx. Reference Naming: Use PascalCase for React components and camelCase for their instances. eslint: react/jsx-pascal-case // bad import reservationCard from './ReservationCard'; // good import ReservationCard from './ReservationCard'; // bad const ReservationItem = <ReservationCard />; // good const reservationItem = <ReservationCard />; Copy Component Naming: Use the filename as the component name. For example, ReservationCard.jsx should have a reference name of ReservationCard. However, for root components of a directory, use index.jsx as the filename and use the directory name as the component name: // bad import Footer from './Footer/Footer'; // bad import Footer from './Footer/index'; // good import Footer from './Footer'; Copy Higher-order Component Naming: Use a composite of the higher-order componentâ€™s name and the passed-in componentâ€™s name as the displayName on the generated component. For example, the higher-order component withFoo(), when passed a component Bar should produce a component with a displayName of withFoo(Bar). Why? A componentâ€™s displayName may be used by developer tools or in error messages, and having a value that clearly expresses this relationship helps people understand what is happening. // bad export default function withFoo(WrappedComponent) { return function WithFoo(props) { return <WrappedComponent {...props} foo />; } } // good export default function withFoo(WrappedComponent) { function WithFoo(props) { return <WrappedComponent {...props} foo />; } const wrappedComponentName = WrappedComponent.displayName || WrappedComponent.name || 'Component'; WithFoo.displayName = `withFoo(${wrappedComponentName})`; return WithFoo; } Copy Props Naming: Avoid using DOM component prop names for different purposes. Why? People expect props like style and className to mean one specific thing. Varying this API for a subset of your app makes the code less readable and less maintainable, and may cause bugs. // bad <MyComponent style="fancy" /> // bad <MyComponent className="fancy" /> // good <MyComponent variant="fancy" /> Copy

title: Declarationâ€‹
content: Do not use displayName for naming components. Instead, name the component by reference. // bad export default React.createClass({ displayName: 'ReservationCard', // stuff goes here }); // good export default class ReservationCard extends React.Component { } Copy

title: Alignmentâ€‹
content: Follow these alignment styles for JSX syntax. eslint: react/jsx-closing-bracket-location react/jsx-closing-tag-location // bad <Foo superLongParam="bar" anotherSuperLongParam="baz" /> // good <Foo superLongParam="bar" anotherSuperLongParam="baz" /> // if props fit in one line then keep it on the same line <Foo bar="bar" /> // children get indented normally <Foo superLongParam="bar" anotherSuperLongParam="baz" > <Quux /> </Foo> // bad {showButton && <Button /> } // bad { showButton && <Button /> } // good {showButton && ( <Button /> )} // good {showButton && <Button />} Copy

title: Quotesâ€‹
content: Always use double quotes (") for JSX attributes, but single quotes (') for all other JS. eslint: jsx-quotes Why? Regular HTML attributes also typically use double quotes instead of single, so JSX attributes mirror this convention. // bad <Foo bar='bar' /> // good <Foo bar="bar" /> // bad <Foo style={{ left: "20px" }} /> // good <Foo style={{ left: '20px' }} /> Copy

title: Spacingâ€‹
content: Always include a single space in your self-closing tag. eslint: no-multi-spaces, react/jsx-tag-spacing // bad <Foo/> // very bad <Foo /> // bad <Foo /> // good <Foo /> Copy Do not pad JSX curly braces with spaces. eslint: react/jsx-curly-spacing // bad <Foo bar={ baz } /> // good <Foo bar={baz} /> Copy

title: Propsâ€‹
content: Always use camelCase for prop names. // bad <Foo UserName="hello" phone_number={12345678} /> // good <Foo userName="hello" phoneNumber={12345678} /> Copy Omit the value of the prop when it is explicitly true. eslint: react/jsx-boolean-value // bad <Foo hidden={true} /> // good <Foo hidden /> // good <Foo hidden /> Copy Always include an alt prop on <img> tags. If the image is presentational, alt can be an empty string or the <img> must have role="presentation". eslint: jsx-a11y/alt-text // bad <img src="hello.jpg" /> // good <img src="hello.jpg" alt="Me waving hello" /> // good <img src="hello.jpg" alt="" /> // good <img src="hello.jpg" role="presentation" /> Copy Do not use words like "image", "photo", or "picture" in <img> alt props. eslint: jsx-a11y/img-redundant-alt Why? Screenreaders already announce img elements as images, so there is no need to include this information in the alt text. // bad <img src="hello.jpg" alt="Picture of me waving hello" /> // good <img src="hello.jpg" alt="Me waving hello" /> Copy Use only valid, non-abstract ARIA roles. eslint: jsx-a11y/aria-role // bad - not an ARIA role <div role="datepicker" /> // bad - abstract ARIA role <div role="range" /> // good <div role="button" /> Copy Do not use accessKey on elements. eslint: jsx-a11y/no-access-key Why? Inconsistencies between keyboard shortcuts and keyboard commands used by people using screenreaders and keyboards complicate accessibility. // bad <div accessKey="h" /> // good <div /> Copy Avoid using an array index as key prop, prefer a stable ID. eslint: react/no-array-index-key Why? Not using a stable ID is an anti-pattern because it can negatively impact performance and cause issues with component state. We donâ€™t recommend using indexes for keys if the order of items may change. // bad {todos.map((todo, index) => <Todo {...todo} key={index} /> )} // good {todos.map(todo => ( <Todo {...todo} key={todo.id} /> ))} Copy Always define explicit defaultProps for all non-required props. Why? propTypes are a form of documentation, and providing defaultProps means the reader of your code doesnâ€™t have to assume as much. In addition, it can mean that your code can omit certain type checks. // bad function SFC({ foo, bar, children }) { return <div>{foo}{bar}{children}</div>; } SFC.propTypes = { foo: PropTypes.number.isRequired, bar: PropTypes.string, children: PropTypes.node, }; // good function SFC({ foo, bar, children }) { return <div>{foo}{bar}{children}</div>; } SFC.propTypes = { foo: PropTypes.number.isRequired, bar: PropTypes.string, children: PropTypes.node, }; SFC.defaultProps = { bar: '', children: null, }; Copy Use spread props sparingly. Why? Otherwise youâ€™re more likely to pass unnecessary props down to components. And for React v15.6.1 and older, you could pass invalid HTML attributes to the DOM. Exceptions: HOCs that proxy down props and hoist propTypes function HOC(WrappedComponent) { return class Proxy extends React.Component { Proxy.propTypes = { text: PropTypes.string, isLoading: PropTypes.bool }; render() { return <WrappedComponent {...this.props} /> } } } Copy Spreading objects with known, explicit props. This can be particularly useful when testing React components with Mochaâ€™s beforeEach construct. export default function Foo { const props = { text: '', isPublished: false } return (<div {...props} />); } Copy Notes for use: Filter out unnecessary props when possible. Also, use prop-types-exact to help prevent bugs. // bad render() { const { irrelevantProp, ...relevantProps } = this.props; return <WrappedComponent {...this.props} /> } // good render() { const { irrelevantProp, ...relevantProps } = this.props; return <WrappedComponent {...relevantProps} /> } Copy

title: Refsâ€‹
content: Always use ref callbacks. eslint: react/no-string-refs // bad <Foo ref="myRef" /> // good <Foo ref={(ref) => { this.myRef = ref; }} /> Copy

title: Parenthesesâ€‹
content: Wrap JSX tags in parentheses when they span more than one line. eslint: react/jsx-wrap-multilines // bad render() { return <MyComponent variant="long body" foo="bar"> <MyChild /> </MyComponent>; } // good render() { return ( <MyComponent variant="long body" foo="bar"> <MyChild /> </MyComponent> ); } // good, when single line render() { const body = <div>hello</div>; return <MyComponent>{body}</MyComponent>; } Copy

title: Tagsâ€‹
content: Always self-close tags that have no children. eslint: react/self-closing-comp // bad <Foo variant="stuff"></Foo> // good <Foo variant="stuff" /> Copy If your component has multiline properties, close its tag on a new line. eslint: react/jsx-closing-bracket-location // bad <Foo bar="bar" baz="baz" /> // good <Foo bar="bar" baz="baz" /> Copy

title: Methodsâ€‹
content: Use arrow functions to close over local variables. It is handy when you need to pass additional data to an event handler. Although, make sure they do not massively hurt performance, in particular when passed to custom components that might be PureComponents, because they will trigger a possibly needless rerender every time. function ItemList(props) { return ( <ul> {props.items.map((item, index) => ( <Item key={item.key} onClick={(event) => { doSomethingWith(event, item.name, index); }} /> ))} </ul> ); } Copy Bind event handlers for the render method in the constructor. eslint: react/jsx-no-bind Why? A bind call in the render path creates a brand new function on every single render. Do not use arrow functions in class fields, because it makes them challenging to test and debug, and can negatively impact performance, and because conceptually, class fields are for data, not logic. // bad class extends React.Component { onClickDiv() { // do stuff } render() { return <div onClick={this.onClickDiv.bind(this)} />; } } // very bad class extends React.Component { onClickDiv = () => { // do stuff } render() { return <div onClick={this.onClickDiv} /> } } // good class extends React.Component { constructor(props) { super(props); this.onClickDiv = this.onClickDiv.bind(this); } onClickDiv() { // do stuff } render() { return <div onClick={this.onClickDiv} />; } } Copy Do not use underscore prefix for internal methods of a React component. Why? Underscore prefixes are sometimes used as a convention in other languages to denote privacy. But, unlike those languages, there is no native support for privacy in JavaScript, everything is public. Regardless of your intentions, adding underscore prefixes to your properties does not actually make them private, and any property (underscore-prefixed or not) should be treated as being public. See issues #1024, and #490 for a more in-depth discussion. // bad React.createClass({ _onClickSubmit() { // do stuff }, // other stuff }); // good class extends React.Component { onClickSubmit() { // do stuff } // other stuff } Copy Be sure to return a value in your render methods. eslint: react/require-render-return // bad render() { (<div />); } // good render() { return (<div />); } Copy

title: Orderingâ€‹
content: Ordering for class extends React.Component: optional static methodsconstructorgetChildContextcomponentWillMountcomponentDidMountcomponentWillReceivePropsshouldComponentUpdatecomponentWillUpdatecomponentDidUpdatecomponentWillUnmountclickHandlers or eventHandlers like onClickSubmit() or onChangeDescription()getter methods for render like getSelectReason() or getFooterContent()optional render methods like renderNavigation() or renderProfilePicture()render How to define propTypes, defaultProps, contextTypes, etc... import React from 'react'; import PropTypes from 'prop-types'; const propTypes = { id: PropTypes.number.isRequired, url: PropTypes.string.isRequired, text: PropTypes.string, }; const defaultProps = { text: 'Hello World', }; class Link extends React.Component { static methodsAreOk() { return true; } render() { return <a href={this.props.url} data-id={this.props.id}>{this.props.text}</a>; } } Link.propTypes = propTypes; Link.defaultProps = defaultProps; export default Link; Copy Ordering for React.createClass: eslint: react/sort-comp displayNamepropTypescontextTypeschildContextTypesmixinsstaticsdefaultPropsgetDefaultPropsgetInitialStategetChildContextcomponentWillMountcomponentDidMountcomponentWillReceivePropsshouldComponentUpdatecomponentWillUpdatecomponentDidUpdatecomponentWillUnmountclickHandlers or eventHandlers like onClickSubmit() or onChangeDescription()getter methods for render like getSelectReason() or getFooterContent()optional render methods like renderNavigation() or renderProfilePicture()render

title: isMountedâ€‹
content: Do not use isMounted. eslint: react/no-is-mounted Why? isMounted is an anti-pattern, is not available when using ES6 classes, and is on its way to being officially deprecated.

title: Official Typescript Documentationâ€‹
content: Familiar With TypeScript already? The starting point for learning TypeScript TypeScript Best Practicesâ€Š-â€ŠSemicolons and Spacing

title: Generalâ€‹
content: No Unused Expressions We shouldn't have unused expressions in our code. If we have them, we should remove them. // Bad ğŸ‘ a + b; // Good ğŸ‘ let add = a + b; Copy Filename Name files with camelCase. Reason: Conventional across many JS teams. accordion.tsx myControl.tsx stringUtils.ts map.ts Copy

title: Variables and Functionâ€‹
content: Use camelCase for variable and function names Reason: Conventional JavaScript // Bad ğŸ‘ var FooVar; function BarFunc() { } // Good ğŸ‘ var fooVar; function barFunc() { } Copy No Unused Variables @typescript-eslint/no-unused-vars Likewise, if we have unused variables, then we should remove them. // Bad ğŸ‘ var num1 = 10; var num2 = 7; var result = num1 + 7; // Good ğŸ‘ var num1 = 10; var result = num1 + 7; // Good ğŸ‘ var num1 = 10; var num2 = 7; var result = num1 + num2; Copy Donâ€™t Use Variables Before theyâ€™re Defined With variables that are declared withÂ var we can reference the variable before theyâ€™re defined, but the value will beÂ undefined. This is because the variable is hoisted. let andÂ const solve this problem since they arenâ€™t hoisted. Therefore, we should useÂ let orÂ const variables. This way, if we reference those variables, weâ€™ll get an error. // Bad ğŸ‘ var hoisted; console.log(hoisted); // will be undefined; // Good ğŸ‘ let notHoisted; const alsoNotHoisted; console.log(notHoisted); // Will throw an error (which is what we want in this case); console.log(alsoNotHoisted); // Will also throw an error (which is what we want in this case); Copy Replace Magic Numbers with Named Constants @typescript-eslint/prefer-as-const If we have numbers that are used as constants repeatedly but arenâ€™t assigned to a constant, then we should assign it to one. This way, we can change it once and the value will be reflected everywhere. Also, named constants tell us the meaning of the number. Therefore, instead of writing: // Bad ğŸ‘ enum Foo { bar = 1 } // Good ğŸ‘ const NUMBER_OF_BARS = 1; enum Foo { bar = NUMBER_OF_BARS } Copy Donâ€™t Use async if await isnâ€™t Used Inside the Function @typescript-eslint/require-await We should useÂ asyncÂ functions only if we have toÂ awaitÂ something inside it. For instance, if we have something like: // Bad ğŸ‘ const foo = async () => "bar"; // Good ğŸ‘ const foo = async () => { const url = "some.domain.com"; let response = await fetch(url, { method: 'GET' }); } Copy then we should use a normal function. Return Awaited Values Consistently We should not haveÂ returnÂ andÂ awaitÂ on the same line since the promises may not have resolved yet. Instead, put them on separate lines. The only exception to this is that we can putÂ returnÂ andÂ awaitÂ on the same line inside aÂ tryÂ block to catch errors from another promised-based function // Bad ğŸ‘ async function foo() { return await bar(); } // Good ğŸ‘ async function foo() { const val = await bar(); return val; } // Good ğŸ‘ async function foo() { try { return await bar(); } catch (error) {} } Copy

title: Arrayâ€‹
content: Annotate arrays as foos:Foo[] instead of foos:Array<Foo>. Reasons: Its easier to read. Its used by the TypeScript team. Makes easier to know something is an array as the mind is trained to detect []. // Bad ğŸ‘ foos:Array<Foo>; // Good ğŸ‘ foos:Foo[]; Copy

title: Stringsâ€‹
content: Prefer single quotes (') unless escaping. Reason: More JavaScript teams do this (e.g. airbnb, standard, npm, node, google/angular, facebook/react). Its easier to type (no shift needed on most keyboards). Prettier team recommends single quotes as well Double quotes are not without merit: Allows easier copy paste of objects into JSON. Allows people to use other languages to work without changing their quote character. Allows you to use apostrophes e.g. He's not going.. But I'd rather not deviate from where the JS Community is fairly decided. // bad ğŸ‘ var foo = "bad"; // good ğŸ‘ var foo = 'bar'; Copy When you can't use double quotes, try using back ticks (`). @typescript-eslint/restrict-template-expressions Reason: These generally represent the intent of complex enough strings. // good ğŸ‘ var foo = `this foo has a dynamic ${bar}`; Copy Have Consistent Use of Backticks, Double Quotes or Single Quotes We should use backticks or quotes in a consistent manner for declaring strings. Better yet, we should use backticks since theyâ€™ll create template strings, which are more flexible. They allow expressions to be embedded in it.

title: Classâ€‹
content: Use PascalCase for class names. Reason: This is actually fairly conventional in standard JavaScript. // Bad ğŸ‘ class fooBoo { } // Good ğŸ‘ class FooBoo { } Copy Use camelCase of class members and methods Reason: Naturally follows from variable and function naming convention. // Bad ğŸ‘ class Foo { BarVar: number; BazFunc() { } } // Good ğŸ‘ class Foo { barVar: number; bazFunc() { } } Copy No Useless Constructors @typescript-eslint/no-useless-constructor We shouldnâ€™t have useless constructors. // Bad ğŸ‘ class A { constructor () { } } // Bad ğŸ‘ class B extends A { constructor (value) { super(value); } } Copy Theyâ€™re both redundant so they should be removed.

title: Interfaceâ€‹
content: Use PascalCase for name. Reason: Similar to class // Bad ğŸ‘ interface themeProps { color: string; } // Good ğŸ‘ interface ThemeProps { color: string; } Copy Use camelCase for members. Reason: Similar to class // Bad ğŸ‘ interface ColorProps { FirstColor: string; second-color: string; } // Good ğŸ‘ interface ColorProps { firstColor: string; secondColor: string; } Copy Don't prefix with I Reason: Unconventional. lib.d.ts defines important interfaces without an I (e.g. Window, Document etc). // Bad ğŸ‘ interface IFoo { } // Good ğŸ‘ interface Foo { } Copy

title: Typeâ€‹
content: Use PascalCase for name. Reason: Similar to class // Bad ğŸ‘ type infoBaseProps = 'htmlFor' | 'className' | 'children' | 'id'; // Good ğŸ‘ type InfoBaseProps = 'htmlFor' | 'className' | 'children' | 'id'; Copy Use camelCase for members. Reason: Similar to class // Bad ğŸ‘ type Animal = { animalrace: string } // Good ğŸ‘ type Animal = { animalRace: string } Copy

title: Type vs. Interfaceâ€‹
content: Use type when you might need a union or intersection: // Good ğŸ‘ type Foo = number | { someProperty: number } Copy Use interface when you want extends or implements e.g // Good ğŸ‘ interface Foo { foo: string; } interface FooBar extends Foo { bar: string; } class X implements FooBar { foo: string; bar: string; } Copy

title: Namespaceâ€‹
content: Use PascalCase for names Reason: Convention followed by the TypeScript team. Namespaces are effectively just a class with static members. Class names are PascalCase => Namespace names are PascalCase // Bad ğŸ‘ namespace fooBaz { } // Good ğŸ‘ namespace FooBaz { } Copy Enum Use PascalCase for enum names Reason: Similar to Class. Is a Type. // Bad ğŸ‘ enum colorOne { } // Good ğŸ‘ enum ColorOne { } Copy Use PascalCase for enum member Reason: Convention followed by TypeScript team i.e. the language creators e.g SyntaxKind.StringLiteral. Also helps with translation (code generation) of other languages into TypeScript // Bad ğŸ‘ enum Color { redHue } // Good ğŸ‘ enum Color { RedHue } Copy

title: Null vs. Undefinedâ€‹
content: Prefer not to use either for explicit unavailability Reason: these values are commonly used to keep a consistent structure between values. In TypeScript you use types to denote the structure // Bad ğŸ‘ let foo = { x:123, y:undefined }; // Good ğŸ‘ let foo:{ x:number, y?:number } = { x:123 }; Copy Use undefined in general (do consider returning an object like {valid:boolean,value?:Foo} instead) // Bad ğŸ‘ return null; // Good ğŸ‘ return undefined; Copy Use null where its a part of the API or conventional Reason: It is conventional in Node.js e.g. error is null for NodeBack style callbacks. // Bad ğŸ‘ cb(undefined) // Good ğŸ‘ cb(null) Copy Use truthy check for objects being null or undefined // Bad ğŸ‘ if (error === null) // Good ğŸ‘ if (error) Copy Use == null / != null (not === / !==) to check for null / undefined on primitives as it works for both null/undefined but not other falsy values (like '',0,false) e.g. // Bad ğŸ‘ if (error !== null) // does not rule out undefined // Good ğŸ‘ if (error != null) // rules out both null and undefined Copy

title: Tabs vs. Spacesâ€‹
content: Use tabs over spaces. Reason: Use tabs for indenting your code. With tabs users can choose their desired width. This has positive implications for accessibility and screenreaders, putting people in control of how they want to view the code. // bad ğŸ‘ function foo() { âˆ™âˆ™let name; } // bad ğŸ‘ function bar() { âˆ™let name; } // good ğŸ‘ function baz() { âˆ™ let name; } Copy

title: Semicolonsâ€‹
content: Use semicolons. Reasons: The usage of semicolons is a core value of our community. Consider the points of the opposition, but be a traditionalist when it comes to abusing error correction mechanisms for cheap syntactic pleasures. Explicit semicolons helps language formatting tools give consistent results. Missing ASI (automatic semicolon insertion) can trip new devs. // Bad ğŸ‘ let x = 5 // Good ğŸ‘ let x = 5; Copy We should put in semicolons in our code instead of letting the JavaScript interpreter add them for us in unexpected places. Remove Useless Semicolons @typescript-eslint/no-extra-semi We should remove duplicate semicolons in our code. We only need one semicolon at the end of a statement. // Bad ğŸ‘ let x = 5;; // Good ğŸ‘ let x = 5; Copy Require Semicolons Instead of Automatic Semicolon Insertion Instead of letting the Javascript interpreter put in semicolons for us, we should put them in ourselves. // Bad ğŸ‘ function returnObject() { return //<-----semi colon will be inserted causing an error. { key: value }; } // Good ğŸ‘ function returnObject() { return { key: value }; } Copy

title: Import / Exportâ€‹
content: Avoid export default Avoid export default in TypeScript because of the maintainability and DX issues outlined in Typescript Deep Dive - Avoid Export Default. Example: // foo.ts class Foo { } export default Foo; Copy // bar.ts import Foo from "./foo"; Copy If you refactor Foo in foo.ts it will not rename it in bar.ts.If you end up needing to export more stuff from foo.ts (which is what many of your files will have) then you have to juggle the import syntax // Bad ğŸ‘ // foo.ts export default class Foo { return { key: value }; } // bar.ts import Foo from './foo'; // Good ğŸ‘ // foo.ts export class Foo { return { key: value }; } // bar.ts import { Foo } from "./foo"; Copy

title: Tabs for Indentationâ€‹
content: Use tabs for indenting your code. With tabs users can choose their desired width. This has positive implications for accessibility and screenreaders, putting people in control of how they want to view the code.

title: Newlinesâ€‹
content: Use UNIX-style newlines (\n), and a newline character as the last character of a file. Windows-style newlines (\r\n) are forbidden inside any repository.

title: No trailing whitespaceâ€‹
content: Always clean up any trailing whitespace in your .js files before committing.

title: Use semicolonsâ€‹
content: According to scientific research, the usage of semicolons is a core value of our community. Consider the points of the opposition, but be a traditionalist when it comes to abusing error correction mechanisms for cheap syntactic pleasures.

title: 100 characters per lineâ€‹
content: Limit your lines to 100 characters.

title: Use single quotesâ€‹
content: Use single quotes, unless you are writing JSON. This helps you separate your objects' strings from normal strings. // bad ğŸ‘ var foo = "bad"; // good ğŸ‘ var foo = 'bar'; Copy Opening braces go on the same line, Your opening braces go on the same line as the statement. // bad ğŸ‘ if (true) { console.log('losing'); } // good ğŸ‘ if (true) { console.log('winning'); } Copy Also, notice the use of whitespace before and after the condition statement. What if you want to write 'else' or 'else if' along with your 'if'... // bad ğŸ‘ if (true) { console.log('losing'); } else if (false) { console.log('this is bad'); } else { console.log('not good'); } // good ğŸ‘ if (true) { console.log('winning'); } else if (false) { console.log('this is good'); } else { console.log('finally'); } Copy

title: Declare one variable per var statementâ€‹
content: Declare one variable per var statement, it makes it easier to re-order the lines. // bad ğŸ‘ var keys = ['foo', 'bar'], values = [23, 42], object = {}, key; // good ğŸ‘ var keys = ['foo', 'bar']; var values = [23, 42]; var object = {}; Copy

title: Use tabsâ€‹
content: eslint: indent // bad ğŸ‘ function foo() { âˆ™âˆ™let name; } // bad ğŸ‘ function bar() { âˆ™let name; } // good ğŸ‘ function baz() { âˆ™ let name; } Copy

title: Space Before Blocksâ€‹
content: Place 1 space before the leading brace. eslint: space-before-blocks // bad ğŸ‘ function test(){ console.log('test'); } // good ğŸ‘ function test() { console.log('test'); } // bad ğŸ‘ dog.set('attr',{ age: '1 year', breed: 'Bernese Mountain Dog', }); // good ğŸ‘ dog.set('attr', { age: '1 year', breed: 'Bernese Mountain Dog', }); Copy

title: Keyword Spacingâ€‹
content: Place 1 space before the opening parenthesis in control statements (if, while etc.). Place no space between the argument list and the function name in function calls and declarations. eslint: keyword-spacing // bad ğŸ‘ if(isJedi) { fight (); } // good ğŸ‘ if (isJedi) { fight(); } // bad ğŸ‘ function fight () { console.log ('Swooosh!'); } // good ğŸ‘ function fight() { console.log('Swooosh!'); } Copy

title: Space Around Infix Operatorsâ€‹
content: Set off operators with spaces. eslint: space-infix-ops // bad ğŸ‘ const x=y+5; // good ğŸ‘ const x = y + 5; Copy

title: End of Fileâ€‹
content: End files with a single newline character. eslint: eol-last // bad ğŸ‘ import { es6 } from './AirbnbStyleGuide'; // ... export default es6; Copy // bad ğŸ‘ import { es6 } from './AirbnbStyleGuide'; // ... export default es6;â†µ â†µ Copy // good ğŸ‘ import { es6 } from './AirbnbStyleGuide'; // ... export default es6;â†µ Copy

title: Chained Callsâ€‹
content: Use indentation when making long method chains (more than 2 method chains). Use a leading dot, which emphasizes that the line is a method call, not a new statement. eslint: newline-per-chained-calleslint: no-whitespace-before-property // bad ğŸ‘ $('#items').find('.selected').highlight().end().find('.open').updateCount(); // bad ğŸ‘ $('#items'). find('.selected'). highlight(). end(). find('.open'). updateCount(); // good ğŸ‘ $('#items') .find('.selected') .highlight() .end() .find('.open') .updateCount(); // bad ğŸ‘ const leds = stage.selectAll('.led').data(data).enter().append('svg:svg').classed('led', true) .attr('width', (radius + margin) * 2).append('svg:g') .attr('transform', `translate(${radius + margin},${radius + margin})`) .call(tron.led); // good ğŸ‘ const leds = stage.selectAll('.led') .data(data) .enter().append('svg:svg') .classed('led', true) .attr('width', (radius + margin) * 2) .append('svg:g') .attr('transform', `translate(${radius + margin},${radius + margin})`) .call(tron.led); // good ğŸ‘ const leds = stage.selectAll('.led').data(data); Copy

title: Paddingâ€‹
content: Blank Linesâ€‹ Leave a blank line after blocks and before the next statement. // bad ğŸ‘ if (foo) { return bar; } return baz; // good ğŸ‘ if (foo) { return bar; } return baz; // bad ğŸ‘ const obj = { foo() { }, bar() { }, }; return obj; // good ğŸ‘ const obj = { foo() { }, bar() { }, }; return obj; // bad ğŸ‘ const arr = [ function foo() { }, function bar() { }, ]; return arr; // good ğŸ‘ const arr = [ function foo() { }, function bar() { }, ]; return arr; Copy Padded Blocksâ€‹ Do not pad your blocks with blank lines. eslint: padded-blocks // bad ğŸ‘ function bar() { console.log(foo); } // bad ğŸ‘ if (baz) { console.log(qux); } else { console.log(foo); } // bad ğŸ‘ class Foo { constructor(bar) { this.bar = bar; } } // good ğŸ‘ function bar() { console.log(foo); } // good ğŸ‘ if (baz) { console.log(qux); } else { console.log(foo); } Copy No Multiple Blank Linesâ€‹ Do not use multiple blank lines to pad your code. eslint: no-multiple-empty-lines // bad ğŸ‘ class Person { constructor(fullName, email, birthday) { this.fullName = fullName; this.email = email; this.setAge(birthday); } setAge(birthday) { const today = new Date(); const age = this.getAge(today, birthday); this.age = age; } getAge(today, birthday) { // .. } } // good ğŸ‘ class Person { constructor(fullName, email, birthday) { this.fullName = fullName; this.email = email; this.setAge(birthday); } setAge(birthday) { const today = new Date(); const age = getAge(today, birthday); this.age = age; } getAge(today, birthday) { // .. } } Copy

title: Spacingâ€‹
content: Parentheses Spacingâ€‹ Do not add spaces inside parentheses. eslint: space-in-parens // bad ğŸ‘ function bar( foo ) { return foo; } // good ğŸ‘ function bar(foo) { return foo; } // bad ğŸ‘ if ( foo ) { console.log(foo); } // good ğŸ‘ if (foo) { console.log(foo); } Copy Inside Bracketsâ€‹ Do not add spaces inside brackets. eslint: array-bracket-spacing // bad ğŸ‘ const foo = [ 1, 2, 3 ]; console.log(foo[ 0 ]); // good ğŸ‘ const foo = [1, 2, 3]; console.log(foo[0]); Copy Inside Curly Bracesâ€‹ Add spaces inside curly braces. eslint: object-curly-spacing // bad ğŸ‘ const foo = {clark: 'kent'}; // good ğŸ‘ const foo = { clark: 'kent' }; Copy Max Lengthâ€‹ Avoid having lines of code that are longer than 100 characters (including whitespace). Note: long strings are exempt from this rule, and should not be broken up. eslint: max-len Why? This ensures readability and maintainability. // bad ğŸ‘ const foo = jsonData && jsonData.foo && jsonData.foo.bar && jsonData.foo.bar.baz && jsonData.foo.bar.baz.quux && jsonData.foo.bar.baz.quux.xyzzy; // bad ğŸ‘ $.ajax({ method: 'POST', url: 'https://airbnb.com/', data: { name: 'John' } }).done(() => console.log('Congratulations!')).fail(() => console.log('You have failed this city.')); // good ğŸ‘ const foo = jsonData && jsonData.foo && jsonData.foo.bar && jsonData.foo.bar.baz && jsonData.foo.bar.baz.quux && jsonData.foo.bar.baz.quux.xyzzy; // good ğŸ‘ $.ajax({ method: 'POST', url: 'https://airbnb.com/', data: { name: 'John' }, }) .done(() => console.log('Congratulations!')) .fail(() => console.log('You have failed this city.')); Copy Block Spacingâ€‹ Require consistent spacing inside an open block token and the next token on the same line. This rule also enforces consistent spacing inside a close block token and previous token on the same line. eslint: block-spacing // bad ğŸ‘ function foo() {return true;} if (foo) { bar = 0;} // good ğŸ‘ function foo() { return true; } if (foo) { bar = 0; } Copy Comma Spacingâ€‹ Avoid spaces before commas and require a space after commas. eslint: comma-spacing // bad ğŸ‘ var foo = 1,bar = 2; var arr = [1 , 2]; // good ğŸ‘ var foo = 1, bar = 2; var arr = [1, 2]; Copy Computed Property Spacingâ€‹ Enforce spacing inside of computed property brackets. eslint: computed-property-spacing // bad ğŸ‘ obj[foo ] obj[ 'foo'] var x = {[ b ]: a} obj[foo[ bar ]] // good ğŸ‘ obj[foo] obj['foo'] var x = { [b]: a } obj[foo[bar]] Copy Function Spacingâ€‹ Avoid spaces between functions and their invocations. eslint: func-call-spacing // bad ğŸ‘ func (); func (); // good ğŸ‘ func(); Copy Key Spacingâ€‹ Enforce spacing between keys and values in object literal properties. eslint: key-spacing // bad ğŸ‘ var obj = { foo : 42 }; var obj2 = { foo:42 }; // good ğŸ‘ var obj = { foo: 42 }; Copy Trailing Spacesâ€‹ Avoid trailing spaces at the end of lines. eslint: no-trailing-spaces Multiple Empty Linesâ€‹ Avoid multiple empty lines, only allow one newline at the end of files, and avoid a newline at the beginning of files. eslint: no-multiple-empty-lines // bad ğŸ‘ - multiple empty lines var x = 1; var y = 2; // bad ğŸ‘ - 2+ newlines at end of file var x = 1; var y = 2; // bad ğŸ‘ - 1+ newline(s) at beginning of file var x = 1; var y = 2; // good ğŸ‘ var x = 1; var y = 2; Copy

title: Primitivesâ€‹
content: When you access a primitive type you work directly on its value. stringnumberbooleannullundefinedsymbolbigint const foo = 1; let bar = foo; bar = 9; console.log(foo, bar); // => 1, 9 Copy Symbols and BigInts cannot be faithfully polyfilled, so they should not be used when targeting browsers/environments that don't support them natively.

title: Complex:â€‹
content: When you access a complex type you work on a reference to its value. objectarrayfunction const foo = [1, 2]; const bar = foo; bar[0] = 9; console.log(foo[0], bar[0]); // => 9, 9 Copy

title: Use const for all of your references:â€‹
content: avoid using var. eslint: prefer-const, no-const-assign IMPORTANCE: This ensures that you can't reassign your references, which can lead to bugs and difficult to comprehend code. // bad ğŸ‘ var a = 1; var b = 2; // good ğŸ‘ const a = 1; const b = 2; Copy

title: Use let instead of var.â€‹
content: If you must reassign references, use 'let' instead of 'var'. eslint: no-var IMPORTANCE: let is block-scoped rather than function-scoped like var. // bad ğŸ‘ var count = 1; if (true) { count += 1; } // good ğŸ‘ , use the let. let count = 1; if (true) { count += 1; } Copy

title: Block Scopedâ€‹
content: Note that both let and const are block-scoped. // const and let only exist in the blocks they are defined in. { let a = 1; const b = 1; } console.log(a); // ReferenceError console.log(b); // ReferenceError Copy

title: No New Objectâ€‹
content: Use the literal syntax for object creation. eslint: no-new-object // bad ğŸ‘ const item = new Object(); // good ğŸ‘ const item = {}; Copy

title: Computed Property Namesâ€‹
content: Use computed property names when creating objects with dynamic property names. IMPORTANCE: They allow you to define all the properties of an object in one place. function getKey(k) { return `a key named ${k}`; } // bad ğŸ‘ const obj = { id: 5, name: 'Lorem Ipsum', }; obj[getKey('enabled')] = true; // good ğŸ‘ const obj = { id: 5, name: 'Lorem Ipsum', [getKey('enabled')]: true, }; Copy

title: Object Method Shorthandâ€‹
content: Use object method shorthand. eslint: object-shorthand // bad ğŸ‘ const atom = { value: 1, addValue: function (value) { return atom.value + value; }, }; // good ğŸ‘ const atom = { value: 1, addValue(value) { return atom.value + value; }, }; Copy

title: Property Value Shorthandâ€‹
content: Use property value shorthand. eslint: object-shorthand IMPORTANCE: It is shorter and descriptive. const lukeSkywalker = 'Lorem Ipsum'; // bad ğŸ‘ const obj = { lukeSkywalker: lukeSkywalker, }; // good ğŸ‘ const obj = { lukeSkywalker, }; Copy

title: Shorthand Property Groupingâ€‹
content: Group your shorthand properties at the beginning of your object declaration. IMPORTANCE: It's easier to tell which properties are using the shorthand. const newyorkSubway = 'Newyork Subway'; const newjerseyTransit = 'NewJersy Transit'; // bad ğŸ‘ const obj = { episodeOne: 1, twoJediWalkIntoACantina: 2, newjerseyTransit, episodeThree: 3, mayTheFourth: 4, newyorkSubway, }; // good ğŸ‘ const obj = { newjerseyTransit, newyorkSubway, episodeOne: 1, twoJediWalkIntoACantina: 2, episodeThree: 3, mayTheFourth: 4, }; Copy

title: Quote Propsâ€‹
content: Only quote properties that are invalid identifiers. eslint: quote-props IMPORTANCE: In general we consider it subjectively easier to read. It improves syntax highlighting, and is also more easily optimized by many JS engines. // bad ğŸ‘ const bad = { 'foo': 3, 'bar': 4, 'data-blah': 5, }; // good ğŸ‘ const good = { foo: 3, bar: 4, 'data-blah': 5, }; Copy

title: Object.prototype Methodsâ€‹
content: Do not call Object.prototype methods directly, such as hasOwnProperty, propertyIsEnumerable, and isPrototypeOf. eslint: no-prototype-builtins IMPORTANCE: These methods may be shadowed by properties on the object in question - consider { hasOwnProperty: false } - or, the object may be a null object (Object.create(null)). // bad ğŸ‘ console.log(object.hasOwnProperty(key)); // good ğŸ‘ console.log(Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty.call(object, key)); // best const has = Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty; // cache the lookup once, in module scope. console.log(has.call(object, key)); /* or */ import has from 'has'; // https://www.npmjs.com/package/has console.log(has(object, key)); Copy

title: Object Spread Operatorâ€‹
content: Prefer the object spread operator. over Object.assign to shallow-copy objects. Use the object rest operator to get a new object with certain properties omitted. // very bad ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ const original = { a: 1, b: 2 }; const copy = Object.assign(original, { c: 3 }); // this mutates `original` Ã Â² _Ã Â² delete copy.a; // so does this // bad ğŸ‘ const original = { a: 1, b: 2 }; const copy = Object.assign({}, original, { c: 3 }); // copy => { a: 1, b: 2, c: 3 } // good ğŸ‘ const original = { a: 1, b: 2 }; const copy = { ...original, c: 3 }; // copy => { a: 1, b: 2, c: 3 } const { a, ...noA } = copy; // noA => { b: 2, c: 3 } Copy

title: No Array Constructorâ€‹
content: Use the literal syntax for array creation. eslint: no-array-constructor // bad ğŸ‘ const items = new Array(); // good ğŸ‘ const items = []; Copy

title: Use Arraypushâ€‹
content: Array#push instead of direct assignment to add items to an array. const someStack = []; // bad ğŸ‘ someStack[someStack.length] = 'abracadabra'; // good ğŸ‘ someStack.push('abracadabra'); Copy

title: Array Spreadsâ€‹
content: Use array spreads ... to copy arrays. // bad ğŸ‘ const len = items.length; const itemsCopy = []; let i; for (i = 0; i < len; i += 1) { itemsCopy[i] = items[i]; } // good ğŸ‘ const itemsCopy = [...items]; Copy Use Spreads for Iterable Objectâ€‹ To convert an iterable object to an array, use spreads ... instead of Array.from Array.from. const foo = document.querySelectorAll('.foo'); // good ğŸ‘ const nodes = Array.from(foo); // best const nodes = [...foo]; Copy

title: Using Array.fromâ€‹
content: Array.from for converting an array-like object to an array. const arrLike = { 0: 'foo', 1: 'bar', 2: 'baz', length: 3 }; // bad ğŸ‘ const arr = Array.prototype.slice.call(arrLike); // good ğŸ‘ const arr = Array.from(arrLike); Copy Mapping over Iterablesâ€‹ Use Array.from instead of spread ... for mapping over iterables, because it avoids creating an intermediate array. // bad ğŸ‘ const baz = [...foo].map(bar); // good ğŸ‘ const baz = Array.from(foo, bar); Copy

title: Array Callback Returnâ€‹
content: Use return statements in array method callbacks. It's ok to omit the return if the function body consists of a single statement returning an expression without side effects, following 8.2. eslint: array-callback-return // good ğŸ‘ [1, 2, 3].map((x) => { const y = x + 1; return x * y; }); // good ğŸ‘ [1, 2, 3].map((x) => x + 1); // bad ğŸ‘ - no returned value means `acc` becomes undefined after the first iteration [[0, 1], [2, 3], [4, 5],].reduce((acc, item, index) => { const flatten = acc.concat(item); }); // good ğŸ‘ [[0, 1], [2, 3], [4, 5],].reduce((acc, item, index) => { const flatten = acc.concat(item); return flatten; }); // bad ğŸ‘ inbox.filter((msg) => { const { subject, author } = msg; if (subject === 'Mockingbird') { return author === 'Harper Lee'; } else { return false; } }); // good ğŸ‘ inbox.filter((msg) => { const { subject, author } = msg; if (subject === 'Mockingbird') { return author === 'Harper Lee'; } return false; }); Copy

title: Line Breaks for Array Bracketsâ€‹
content: Use line breaks after open and before close array brackets if an array has multiple lines // bad ğŸ‘ const arr = [ [0, 1], [2, 3], [4, 5], ]; const objectInArray = [{ id: 1, }, { id: 2, }]; const numberInArray = [ 1, 2 ]; // good ğŸ‘ const arr = [[0, 1], [2, 3], [4, 5]]; const objectInArray = [ { id: 1, }, { id: 2, }, ]; const numberInArray = [ 1, 2 ]; Copy

title: Use Object Destructuringâ€‹
content: Use object destructuring when accessing and using multiple properties of an object. eslint: prefer-destructuring IMPORTANCE: Destructuring saves you from creating temporary references for those properties. // bad ğŸ‘ function getFullName(user) { const firstName = user.firstName; const lastName = user.lastName; return `${firstName} ${lastName}`; } // good ğŸ‘ function getFullName(user) { const { firstName, lastName } = user; return `${firstName} ${lastName}`; } // best function getFullName({ firstName, lastName }) { return `${firstName} ${lastName}`; } Copy

title: Use Array Destructuringâ€‹
content: eslint: prefer-destructuring const arr = [1, 2, 3, 4]; // bad ğŸ‘ const first = arr[0]; const second = arr[1]; // good ğŸ‘ const [first, second] = arr; Copy

title: Multiple Return Valuesâ€‹
content: Use object destructuring for multiple return values, not array destructuring. IMPORTANCE: You can add new properties over time or change the order of things without breaking call sites. // bad ğŸ‘ function processInput(input) { // then a miracle occurs return [left, right, top, bottom]; } // the caller needs to think about the order of return data const [left, __, top] = processInput(input); // good ğŸ‘ function processInput(input) { // then a miracle occurs return { left, right, top, bottom }; } // the caller selects only the data they need const { left, top } = processInput(input); Copy

title: Single Quotesâ€‹
content: Use single quotes '' for strings. eslint: quotes // bad ğŸ‘ const name = 'Capt. Janeway'; // bad ğŸ‘ - template literals should contain interpolation or newlines const name = `Capt. Janeway`; // good ğŸ‘ const name = 'Capt. Janeway'; Copy

title: Broken Stringsâ€‹
content: Strings that cause the line to go over 100 characters should not be written across multiple lines using string concatenation. IMPORTANCE: Broken strings are painful to work with and make code less searchable. // bad ğŸ‘ const errorMessage = 'This is a super long error that was thrown because \ of Batman. When you stop to think about how Batman had anything to do \ with this, you would get nowhere \ fast.'; // bad ğŸ‘ const errorMessage = 'This is a super long error that was thrown because ' + 'of Batman. When you stop to think about how Batman had anything to do ' + 'with this, you would get nowhere fast.'; // good ğŸ‘ const errorMessage = 'This is a super long error that was thrown because of Batman. When you stop to think about how Batman had anything to do with this, you would get nowhere fast.'; Copy

title: Prefer Template Stringsâ€‹
content: When programmatically building up strings, use template strings instead of concatenation. eslint: prefer-template template-curly-spacing IMPORTANCE: Template strings give you a readable, concise syntax with proper newlines and string interpolation features. // bad ğŸ‘ function sayHi(name) { return 'How are you, ' + name + '?'; } // bad ğŸ‘ function sayHi(name) { return ['How are you, ', name, '?'].join(); } // bad ğŸ‘ function sayHi(name) { return `How are you, ${name}?`; } // good ğŸ‘ function sayHi(name) { return `How are you, ${name}?`; } Copy

title: No Evalâ€‹
content: Never use eval() on a string, it opens too many vulnerabilities. eslint: no-eval

title: No Useless Escapesâ€‹
content: Do not unnecessarily escape characters in strings. eslint: no-useless-escape IMPORTANCE: Backslashes harm readability, thus they should only be present when necessary. // bad ğŸ‘ const foo = ''this' is \'quoted\''; // good ğŸ‘ const foo = ''this' is \'quoted\''; const foo = `my name is '${name}'`; Copy

title: Function Styleâ€‹
content: Use named function expressions instead of function declarations. eslint: func-style IMPORTANCE: Function declarations are hoisted, which means that it's easy - too easy - to reference the function before it is defined in the file. This harms readability and maintainability. // bad ğŸ‘ function foo() { // ... } // bad ğŸ‘ const foo = function () { // ... }; // good ğŸ‘ // lexical name distinguished from the variable-referenced invocation(s) const short = function longUniqueMoreDescriptiveLexicalFoo() { // ... }; Copy

title: Wrap Immediately Invoked Functionsâ€‹
content: Wrap immediately invoked function expressions in parentheses. eslint: wrap-iife IMPORTANCE: An immediately invoked function expression is a single unit - wrapping both it, and its invocation parens, in parens, cleanly expresses this. Note that in a world with modules everywhere, you almost never need an IIFE. // immediately-invoked function expression (IIFE) (function () { console.log('Welcome to the Internet. Please follow me.'); })(); Copy

title: No Loop Functionsâ€‹
content: Never declare a function in a non-function block (if, while, etc). Assign the function to a variable instead. eslint: no-loop-func

title: A function declaration is not a statement.â€‹
content: // bad ğŸ‘ if (currentUser) { function test() { console.log('Nope.'); } } // good ğŸ‘ let test; if (currentUser) { test = () => { console.log('Yup.'); }; } Copy

title: Parameters and Argumentsâ€‹
content: argumentsâ€‹ Never name a parameter arguments. This will take precedence over the arguments object that is given to every function scope. // bad ğŸ‘ function foo(name, options, arguments) { // ... } // good ğŸ‘ function foo(name, options, args) { // ... } Copy Prefer Rest Paramsâ€‹ Never use arguments, opt to use rest syntax ... instead. eslint: prefer-rest-params IMPORTANCE: ... is explicit about which arguments you want pulled. // bad ğŸ‘ function concatenateAll() { const args = Array.prototype.slice.call(arguments); return args.join(''); } // good ğŸ‘ function concatenateAll(...args) { return args.join(''); } Copy Default Parameter Syntaxâ€‹ Use default parameter syntax rather than mutating function arguments. // really bad function handleThings(opts) { // No! We shouldn't mutate function arguments. // Double bad: if opts is falsy it'll be set to an object which may // be what you want but it can introduce subtle bugs. opts = opts || {}; // ... } // still bad function handleThings(opts) { if (opts === void 0) { opts = {}; } // ... } // good ğŸ‘ function handleThings(opts = {}) { // ... } Copy Parameter Side Effectsâ€‹ Avoid side effects with default parameters. IMPORTANCE: They are confusing to reason about. var b = 1; // bad ğŸ‘ function count(a = b++) { console.log(a); } count(); // 1 count(); // 2 count(3); // 3 count(); // 3 Copy Default Parameters Lastâ€‹ Always put default parameters last. // bad ğŸ‘ function handleThings(opts = {}, name) { // ... } // good ğŸ‘ function handleThings(name, opts = {}) { // ... } Copy Never Mutate Parameters.â€‹ eslint: no-param-reassign IMPORTANCE: Manipulating objects passed in as parameters can cause unwanted variable side effects in the original caller. // bad ğŸ‘ function f1(obj) { obj.key = 1; } // good ğŸ‘ function f2(obj) { const key = Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty.call(obj, 'key') ? obj.key : 1; } Copy Never Reassign Parameters.â€‹ eslint: no-param-reassign IMPORTANCE: Reassigning parameters can lead to unexpected behavior, especially when accessing the arguments object. It can also cause optimization issues, especially in V8. // bad ğŸ‘ function f1(a) { a = 1; // ... } function f2(a) { if (!a) { a = 1; } // ... } // good ğŸ‘ function f3(a) { const b = a || 1; // ... } function f4(a = 1) { // ... } Copy

title: No New Functionâ€‹
content: Never use the Function constructor to create a new function. eslint: no-new-func IMPORTANCE: Creating a function in this way evaluates a string similarly to eval(), which opens vulnerabilities. // bad ğŸ‘ var add = new Function('a', 'b', 'return a + b'); // still bad var subtract = Function('a', 'b', 'return a - b'); Copy

title: Function Spacingâ€‹
content: Spacing in a function signature. eslint: space-before-function-paren space-before-blocks IMPORTANCE: Consistency is good, and you shouldn't have to add or remove a space when adding or removing a name. // bad ğŸ‘ const f = function () {}; const g = function () {}; const h = function () {}; // good ğŸ‘ const x = function () {}; const y = function a() {}; Copy

title: Prefer Spreadâ€‹
content: Prefer the use of the spread operator ... to call variadic functions. eslint: prefer-spread IMPORTANCE: It's cleaner, you don't need to supply a context, and you can not easily compose new with apply. // bad ğŸ‘ const x = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; console.log.apply(console, x); // good ğŸ‘ const x = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; console.log(...x); // bad ğŸ‘ new (Function.prototype.bind.apply(Date, [null, 2016, 8, 5]))(); // good ğŸ‘ new Date(...[2016, 8, 5]); Copy

title: Function Parentheses Newlineâ€‹
content: Functions with multiline signatures, or invocations, should be indented just like every other multiline. eslint: function-paren-newline // bad ğŸ‘ function foo(bar, baz, quux) { // ... } // good ğŸ‘ function foo( bar, baz, quux, ) { // ... } // bad ğŸ‘ console.log(foo, bar, baz); // good ğŸ‘ console.log( foo, bar, baz, ); Copy

title: Prefer Arrow Callbackâ€‹
content: When you must use an anonymous function (as when passing an inline callback), use arrow function notation. eslint: prefer-arrow-callback, arrow-spacing IMPORTANCE: It creates a version of the function that executes in the context of this, which is usually what you want, and is a more concise syntax. Why not? If you have a fairly complicated function, you might move that logic out into its own named function expression. // bad ğŸ‘ [1, 2, 3].map(function (x) { const y = x + 1; return x * y; }); // good ğŸ‘ [1, 2, 3].map((x) => { const y = x + 1; return x * y; }); Copy

title: Arrow Stylingâ€‹
content: If the function body consists of a single statement, omit the braces and use the implicit return. Otherwise, keep the braces and use a return statement. eslint: arrow-parens, arrow-body-style IMPORTANCE: It reads well when multiple functions are chained together. // bad ğŸ‘ [1, 2, 3].map((number) => { const nextNumber = number + 1; `A string containing the ${nextNumber}.`; }); // good ğŸ‘ [1, 2, 3].map((number) => `A string containing the ${number + 1}.`); // good ğŸ‘ [1, 2, 3].map((number) => { const nextNumber = number + 1; return `A string containing the ${nextNumber}.`; }); // good ğŸ‘ [1, 2, 3].map((number, index) => ({ [index]: number, })); // No implicit return with side effects function foo(callback) { const val = callback(); if (val === true) { // Do something if callback returns true } } let bool = false; // bad ğŸ‘ foo(() => (bool = true)); // good ğŸ‘ foo(() => { bool = true; }); Copy

title: Arrow Readabilityâ€‹
content: In case the expression spans over multiple lines, wrap it in parentheses for better readability. IMPORTANCE: It shows clearly where the function starts and ends. // bad ğŸ‘ ['get', 'post', 'put'].map((httpMethod) => Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty.call( httpMagicObjectWithAVeryLongName, httpMethod ) ); // good ğŸ‘ ['get', 'post', 'put'].map((httpMethod) => Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty.call( httpMagicObjectWithAVeryLongName, httpMethod ) ); Copy

title: Arrow Parenthesesâ€‹
content: Always include parentheses around arguments for clarity and consistency. eslint: arrow-parens IMPORTANCE: Minimizes diff churn when adding or removing arguments. // bad ğŸ‘ [1, 2, 3].map(x => x * x); // good ğŸ‘ [1, 2, 3].map((x) => x * x); // bad ğŸ‘ [1, 2, 3].map(number => ( `A long string with the ${number}. It's so long that we don't want it to take up space on the .map line!` )); // good ğŸ‘ [1, 2, 3].map((number) => ( `A long string with the ${number}. It's so long that we don't want it to take up space on the .map line!` )); // bad ğŸ‘ [1, 2, 3].map(x => { const y = x + 1; return x * y; }); // good ğŸ‘ [1, 2, 3].map((x) => { const y = x + 1; return x * y; }); Copy

title: No Confusing Arrowâ€‹
content: Avoid confusing arrow function syntax (=>) with comparison operators (<=, >=). eslint: no-confusing-arrow // bad ğŸ‘ const itemHeight = (item) => item.height <= 256 ? item.largeSize : item.smallSize; // bad ğŸ‘ const itemHeight = (item) => item.height >= 256 ? item.largeSize : item.smallSize; // good ğŸ‘ const itemHeight = (item) => (item.height <= 256 ? item.largeSize : item.smallSize); // good ğŸ‘ const itemHeight = (item) => { const { height, largeSize, smallSize } = item; return height <= 256 ? largeSize : smallSize; }; Copy

title: Implicit Arrow Linebreakâ€‹
content: Enforce the location of arrow function bodies with implicit returns. eslint: implicit-arrow-linebreak // bad ğŸ‘ (foo) => bar; (foo) => (bar); // good ğŸ‘ (foo) => bar; (foo) => (bar); (foo) => ( bar ) Copy

title: Classâ€‹
content: Always use class. IMPORTANCE: class syntax is more concise and easier to reason about. // bad ğŸ‘ function Queue(contents = []) { this.queue = [...contents]; } Queue.prototype.pop = function () { const value = this.queue[0]; this.queue.splice(0, 1); return value; }; // good ğŸ‘ class Queue { constructor(contents = []) { this.queue = [...contents]; } pop() { const value = this.queue[0]; this.queue.splice(0, 1); return value; } } Copy

title: Extendsâ€‹
content: Use extends for inheritance. IMPORTANCE: It is a built-in way to inherit prototype functionality without breaking instanceof. // bad ğŸ‘ const inherits = require('inherits'); function PeekableQueue(contents) { Queue.apply(this, contents); } inherits(PeekableQueue, Queue); PeekableQueue.prototype.peek = function () { return this.queue[0]; }; // good ğŸ‘ class PeekableQueue extends Queue { peek() { return this.queue[0]; } } Copy

title: Method Chainingâ€‹
content: Methods can return this to help with method chaining. // bad ğŸ‘ Jedi.prototype.jump = function () { this.jumping = true; return true; }; Jedi.prototype.setHeight = function (height) { this.height = height; }; const luke = new Jedi(); luke.jump(); // => true luke.setHeight(20); // => undefined // good ğŸ‘ class Jedi { jump() { this.jumping = true; return this; } setHeight(height) { this.height = height; return this; } } const luke = new Jedi(); luke.jump() .setHeight(20); Copy

title: toString()â€‹
content: Itâ€™s okay to write a custom toString() method, just make sure it works successfully and causes no side effects. class Jedi { constructor(options = {}) { this.name = options.name || 'no name'; } getName() { return this.name; } toString() { return `Jedi - ${this.getName()}`; } } Copy

title: No Useless Constructorâ€‹
content: Classes have a default constructor if one is not specified. An empty constructor function or one that just delegates to a parent class is unnecessary. eslint: no-useless-constructor // bad ğŸ‘ class Jedi { constructor() {} getName() { return this.name; } } // bad ğŸ‘ class Rey extends Jedi { constructor(...args) { super(...args); } } // good ğŸ‘ class Rey extends Jedi { constructor(...args) { super(...args); this.name = 'Rey'; } } Copy

title: No Duplicate Class Membersâ€‹
content: Avoid duplicate class members. eslint: no-dupe-class-members IMPORTANCE: Duplicate class member declarations will silently prefer the last one - having duplicates is almost certainly a bug. // bad ğŸ‘ class Foo { bar() { return 1; } bar() { return 2; } } // good ğŸ‘ class Foo { bar() { return 1; } } // good ğŸ‘ class Foo { bar() { return 2; } } Copy

title: Class Methods Use thisâ€‹
content: Class methods should use this or be made into a static method unless an external library or framework requires to use specific non-static methods. Being an instance method should indicate that it behaves differently based on properties of the receiver. eslint: class-methods-use-this // bad ğŸ‘ class Foo { bar() { console.log('bar'); } } // good ğŸ‘ - this is used class Foo { bar() { console.log(this.bar); } } // good ğŸ‘ - constructor is exempt class Foo { constructor() { // ... } } // good ğŸ‘ - static methods aren't expected to use this class Foo { static bar() { console.log('bar'); } } Copy

title: Import/Exportâ€‹
content: Always use modules (import/export) over a non-standard module system. You can always transpile to your preferred module system. Why? Modules are the future, letâ€™s start using the future now. // bad ğŸ‘ const AirbnbStyleGuide = require('./AirbnbStyleGuide'); module.exports = AirbnbStyleGuide.es6; // ok import AirbnbStyleGuide from './AirbnbStyleGuide'; export default AirbnbStyleGuide.es6; // best import { es6 } from './AirbnbStyleGuide'; export default es6; Copy

title: Wildcardsâ€‹
content: Do not use wildcard imports. Why? This makes sure you have a single default export. // bad ğŸ‘ import * as AirbnbStyleGuide from './AirbnbStyleGuide'; // good ğŸ‘ import AirbnbStyleGuide from './AirbnbStyleGuide'; Copy

title: Export From Importâ€‹
content: And do not export directly from an import. Why? Although the one-liner is concise, having one clear way to import and one clear way to export makes things consistent. // bad ğŸ‘ // filename es6.js export { es6 as default } from './AirbnbStyleGuide'; // good ğŸ‘ // filename es6.js import { es6 } from './AirbnbStyleGuide'; export default es6; Copy

title: No Duplicate Importsâ€‹
content: Only import from a path in one place. eslint: no-duplicate-imports Why? Having multiple lines that import from the same path can make code harder to maintain. // bad ğŸ‘ import foo from 'foo'; // â€¦ some other imports â€¦ // import { named1, named2 } from 'foo'; // good ğŸ‘ import foo, { named1, named2 } from 'foo'; // good ğŸ‘ import foo, { named1, named2, } from 'foo'; Copy

title: Do Not Export Mutable Bindings.â€‹
content: eslint: import/no-mutable-exports Why? Mutation should be avoided in general, but in particular when exporting mutable bindings. While this technique may be needed for some special cases, in general, only constant references should be exported. // bad ğŸ‘ let foo = 3; export { foo }; // good ğŸ‘ const foo = 3; export { foo }; Copy

title: Named and Default Exportâ€‹
content: There are two different types of export, named and default. You can have multiple named exports per module but only one default export. In JS modules with a single export, prefer default export over named export. Note: this is inverted in Typescript, where we prefer named exports and avoid default export. eslint: import/prefer-default-export Why? To encourage more files that only ever export one thing, which is better for readability and maintainability. // okay export default function foo() {} // good ğŸ‘ export function foo() {} Copy Put all imports above non-import statements. eslint: import/first Why? Since imports are hoisted, keeping them all at the top prevents surprising behavior. // bad ğŸ‘ import foo from 'foo'; foo.init(); import bar from 'bar'; // good ğŸ‘ import foo from 'foo'; import bar from 'bar'; foo.init(); Copy

title: Object Curly Newlineâ€‹
content: Multiline imports should be indented just like multiline array and object literals. eslint: object-curly-newline Why? The curly braces follow the same indentation rules as every other curly brace block in the style guide, as do the trailing commas. // bad ğŸ‘ import {longNameA, longNameB, longNameC, longNameD, longNameE} from 'path'; // good ğŸ‘ import { longNameA, longNameB, longNameC, longNameD, longNameE, } from 'path'; Copy

title: No webpack Loader Syntaxâ€‹
content: Disallow Webpack loader syntax in module import statements. eslint: import/no-webpack-loader-syntax Why? Since using Webpack syntax in the imports couples the code to a module bundler. Prefer using the loader syntax in webpack.config.js. // bad ğŸ‘ import fooSass from 'css!sass!foo.scss'; import barCss from 'style!css!bar.css'; // good ğŸ‘ import fooSass from 'foo.scss'; import barCss from 'bar.css'; Copy

title: No JS Filename Extensionsâ€‹
content: Do not include JavaScript filename extensions eslint: import/extensions Why? Including extensions inhibits refactoring, and inappropriately hardcodes implementation details of the module you're importing in every consumer. // bad ğŸ‘ import foo from './foo.js'; import bar from './bar.jsx'; import baz from './baz/index.jsx'; // good ğŸ‘ import foo from './foo'; import bar from './bar'; import baz from './baz'; Copy

title: Iteratorsâ€‹
content: Don't Use Iterators. Prefer JavaScript's higher-order functions instead of loops like for-in or for-of. eslint: no-iterator no-restricted-syntax IMPORTANCE: This enforces our immutable rule. Dealing with pure functions that return values is easier to reason about than side effects. Use map() / every() / filter() / find() / findIndex() / reduce() / some() / ... to iterate over arrays, and Object.keys() / Object.values() / Object.entries() to produce arrays so you can iterate over objects. const numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; // bad ğŸ‘ let sum = 0; for (let num of numbers) { sum += num; } sum === 15; // good ğŸ‘ let sum = 0; numbers.forEach((num) => { sum += num; }); sum === 15; // best (use the functional force) const sum = numbers.reduce((total, num) => total + num, 0); sum === 15; // bad ğŸ‘ const increasedByOne = []; for (let i = 0; i < numbers.length; i++) { increasedByOne.push(numbers[i] + 1); } // good ğŸ‘ const increasedByOne = []; numbers.forEach((num) => { increasedByOne.push(num + 1); }); // best (keeping it functional) const increasedByOne = numbers.map((num) => num + 1); Copy

title: Generatorsâ€‹
content: Donâ€™t Use Generators For Now Why? They donâ€™t transpile well to ES5. Generator Spacingâ€‹ If you must use generators, or if you disregard our advice, make sure their function signature is spaced properly. eslint: generator-star-spacing Why? function and * are part of the same conceptual keyword - * is not a modifier for function, function* is a unique construct, different from function. // bad ğŸ‘ function * foo() { // ... } // bad ğŸ‘ const bar = function * () { // ... }; // bad ğŸ‘ const baz = function *() { // ... }; // bad ğŸ‘ const quux = function*() { // ... }; // bad ğŸ‘ function*foo() { // ... } // bad ğŸ‘ function *foo() { // ... } // very bad function * foo() { // ... } // very bad const wat = function * () { // ... }; // good ğŸ‘ function* foo() { // ... } // good ğŸ‘ const foo = function* () { // ... }; Copy

title: Dot Notationâ€‹
content: Use dot notation when accessing properties. eslint: dot-notation const luke = { jedi: true, age: 28, }; // bad ğŸ‘ const isJedi = luke['jedi']; // good ğŸ‘ const isJedi = luke.jedi; Copy

title: Bracket Notationâ€‹
content: Use bracket notation [] when accessing properties with a variable. const luke = { jedi: true, age: 28, }; function getProp(prop) { return luke[prop]; } const isJedi = getProp('jedi'); Copy

title: No Restricted Propertiesâ€‹
content: Use exponentiation operator ** when calculating exponentiations. eslint: no-restricted-properties. // bad ğŸ‘ const binary = Math.pow(2, 10); // good ğŸ‘ const binary = 2 ** 10; Copy

title: Use const and letâ€‹
content: Always use const or let to declare variables. 'var' is a global variables. We want to avoid using the global namespace. eslint: no-undef prefer-const // bad ğŸ‘ superPower = new SuperPower(); // good ğŸ‘ const superPower = new SuperPower(); Copy

title: One Variableâ€‹
content: Use one const or let declaration per variable or assignment. eslint: one-var IMPORTANCE: It's easier to add new variable declarations this way, and you never have to worry about swapping out a ; for a , or introducing punctuation-only diffs. You can also step through each declaration with the debugger, instead of jumping through all of them at once. // bad ğŸ‘ const items = getItems(), goSportsTeam = true, dragonball = 'z'; // bad ğŸ‘ // (compare to above, and try to spot the mistake) const items = getItems(), goSportsTeam = true; dragonball = 'z'; // good ğŸ‘ const items = getItems(); const goSportsTeam = true; const dragonball = 'z'; Copy

title: Grouping Variablesâ€‹
content: Group all your const and then group all your let. This is helpful when later on you might need to assign a variable depending on one of the previous assigned variables. // bad ğŸ‘ let i, len, dragonball, items = getItems(), goSportsTeam = true; // bad ğŸ‘ let i; const items = getItems(); let dragonball; const goSportsTeam = true; let len; // good ğŸ‘ const goSportsTeam = true; const items = getItems(); let dragonball; let i; let length; Copy

title: Reasonably Placed Variablesâ€‹
content: Assign variables where you need them, but place them in a reasonable place. let and const are block scoped and not function scoped. // bad ğŸ‘ - unnecessary function call function checkName(hasName) { const name = getName(); if (hasName === 'test') { return false; } if (name === 'test') { this.setName(''); return false; } return name; } // good ğŸ‘ function checkName(hasName) { if (hasName === 'test') { return false; } const name = getName(); if (name === 'test') { this.setName(''); return false; } return name; } Copy

title: No Multi Assignâ€‹
content: Don't chain variable assignments. eslint: no-multi-assign Why? Chaining variable assignments creates implicit global variables. // bad ğŸ‘ (function example() { // JavaScript interprets this as // let a = ( b = ( c = 1 ) ); // The let keyword only applies to variable a; variables b and c become // global variables. let a = (b = c = 1); }()); console.log(a); // throws ReferenceError console.log(b); // 1 console.log(c); // 1 // good ğŸ‘ (function example() { let a = 1; let b = a; let c = a; }()); console.log(a); // throws ReferenceError console.log(b); // throws ReferenceError console.log(c); // throws ReferenceError // the same applies for `const` Copy

title: No Unary Incrementsâ€‹
content: Avoid using unary increments and decrements (++, --). eslint no-plusplus Why? Per the eslint documentation, unary increment and decrement statements are subject to automatic semicolon insertion and can cause silent errors with incrementing or decrementing values within an application. It is also more expressive to mutate your values with statements like num += 1 instead of num++ or num ++. Disallowing unary increment and decrement statements also prevents you from pre-incrementing/pre-decrementing values unintentionally which can also cause unexpected behavior in your programs. // bad ğŸ‘ const array = [1, 2, 3]; let num = 1; num++; --num; let sum = 0; let truthyCount = 0; for (let i = 0; i < array.length; i++) { let value = array[i]; sum += value; if (value) { truthyCount++; } } // good ğŸ‘ const array = [1, 2, 3]; let num = 1; num += 1; num -= 1; const sum = array.reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0); const truthyCount = array.filter(Boolean).length; Copy

title: Operator Linebreakâ€‹
content: Avoid linebreaks before or after = in an assignment. If your assignment violates max-len, surround the value in parens. eslint operator-linebreak. Linebreaks surrounding = can obfuscate the value of an assignment. // bad ğŸ‘ const foo = superLongLongLongLongLongLongLongLongFunctionName(); // bad ğŸ‘ const foo = 'superLongLongLongLongLongLongLongLongString'; // good ğŸ‘ const foo = ( superLongLongLongLongLongLongLongLongFunctionName(); ); // good ğŸ‘ const foo = 'superLongLongLongLongLongLongLongLongString'; Copy

title: No Unused Variablesâ€‹
content: Disallow unused variables. eslint: no-unused-vars Why? Variables that are declared and not used anywhere in the code are most likely an error due to incomplete refactoring. Such variables take up space in the code and can lead to confusion by readers. // bad ğŸ‘ var some_unused_var = 42; // Write-only variables are not considered as used. var y = 10; y = 5; // A read for a modification of itself is not considered as used. var z = 0; z = z + 1; // Unused function arguments. function getX(x, y) { return x; } // good ğŸ‘ function getXPlusY(x, y) { return x + y; } var x = 1; var y = a + 2; alert(getXPlusY(x, y)); // 'type' is ignored even if unused because it has a rest property sibling. // This is a form of extracting an object that omits the specified keys. var { type, ...coords } = data; // 'coords' is now the 'data' object without its 'type' property. Copy

title: Object / Array creationâ€‹
content: Use trailing commas and put short declarations on a single line. // bad ğŸ‘ var a = [ 'hello', 'world' ]; var b = {'good': 'code' , is generally: 'pretty' }; // good ğŸ‘ var a = ['hello', 'world']; var b = { good: 'code', 'is generally': 'pretty', }; Copy

title: varâ€‹
content: var declarations get hoisted to the top of their closest enclosing function scope, their assignment does not. const and let declarations are blessed with a new concept called Temporal Dead Zones (TDZ). Itâ€™s important to know why typeof is no longer safe. // we know this wouldnâ€™t work (assuming there // is no notDefined global variable) function example() { console.log(notDefined); // => throws a ReferenceError } // creating a variable declaration after you // reference the variable will work due to // variable hoisting.
