Note: the assignment // value of `true` is not hoisted. function example() { console.log(declaredButNotAssigned); // => undefined var declaredButNotAssigned = true; } // the interpreter is hoisting the variable // declaration to the top of the scope, // which means our example could be rewritten as: function example() { let declaredButNotAssigned; console.log(declaredButNotAssigned); // => undefined declaredButNotAssigned = true; } // using const and let function example() { console.log(declaredButNotAssigned); // => throws a ReferenceError console.log(typeof declaredButNotAssigned); // => throws a ReferenceError const declaredButNotAssigned = true; } Copy

title: Anonymous Function Expressionsâ€‹
content: Anonymous function expressions hoist their variable name, but not the function assignment. function example() { console.log(anonymous); // => undefined anonymous(); // => TypeError anonymous is not a function var anonymous = function () { console.log('anonymous function expression'); }; } Copy

title: Named Function Expressionsâ€‹
content: Named function expressions hoist the variable name, not the function name or the function body. function example() { console.log(named); // => undefined named(); // => TypeError named is not a function superPower(); // => ReferenceError superPower is not defined var named = function superPower() { console.log('Flying'); }; } // the same is true when the function name // is the same as the variable name. function example() { console.log(named); // => undefined named(); // => TypeError named is not a function var named = function named() { console.log('named'); }; } Copy

title: Function Declarationsâ€‹
content: Function declarations hoist their name and the function body. function example() { superPower(); // => Flying function superPower() { console.log('Flying'); } } Copy For more information refer to JavaScript Scoping & Hoisting by Ben Cherry.

title: Equalsâ€‹
content: Must use === and !== over == and !=. eslint: eqeqeq

title: ifâ€‹
content: Conditional statements such as the if statement evaluate their expression using coercion with the ToBoolean abstract method and always follow these simple rules: Objects evaluate to trueUndefined evaluates to falseNull evaluates to falseBooleans evaluate to the value of the booleanNumbers evaluate to false if +0, -0, or NaN, otherwise trueStrings evaluate to false if an empty string '', otherwise true if ([0] && []) { // true // an array (even an empty one) is an object, objects will evaluate to true } Copy

title: Booleans, Strings and Numbersâ€‹
content: Use shortcuts for booleans, but explicit comparisons for strings and numbers. // bad ğŸ‘ if (isValid === true) { // ... } // good ğŸ‘ if (isValid) { // ... } // bad ğŸ‘ if (name) { // ... } // good ğŸ‘ if (name !== '') { // ... } // bad ğŸ‘ if (collection.length) { // ... } // good ğŸ‘ if (collection.length > 0) { // ... } Copy

title: More Infoâ€‹
content: For more information see Truth Equality and JavaScript by Angus Croll.

title: No Case Declarationsâ€‹
content: Use braces to create blocks in case and default clauses that contain lexical declarations (e.g. let, const, function, and class). eslint: no-case-declarations Why? Lexical declarations are visible in the entire switch block but only get initialized when assigned, which only happens when its case is reached. This causes problems when multiple case clauses attempt to define the same thing. // bad ğŸ‘ switch (foo) { case 1: let x = 1; break; case 2: const y = 2; break; case 3: function f() { // ... } break; default: class C {} } // good ğŸ‘ switch (foo) { case 1: { let x = 1; break; } case 2: { const y = 2; break; } case 3: { function f() { // ... } break; } case 4: bar(); break; default: { class C {} } } Copy

title: Ternariesâ€‹
content: Ternaries should not be nested and generally be single line expressions. eslint: no-nested-ternary // bad ğŸ‘ const foo = maybe1 > maybe2 ? 'bar' : value1 > value2 ? 'baz' : null; // split into 2 separated ternary expressions const maybeNull = value1 > value2 ? 'baz' : null; // better const foo = maybe1 > maybe2 ? 'bar' : maybeNull; // best const foo = maybe1 > maybe2 ? 'bar' : maybeNull; Copy Unnecessary Ternariesâ€‹ Avoid unneeded ternary statements. eslint: no-unneeded-ternary // bad ğŸ‘ const foo = a ? a : b; const bar = c ? true : false; const baz = c ? false : true; // good ğŸ‘ const foo = a || b; const bar = !!c; const baz = !c; Copy

title: Mixing Operatorsâ€‹
content: When mixing operators, enclose them in parentheses. The only exception is the standard arithmetic operators: +, -, and ** since their precedence is broadly understood. We recommend enclosing / and * in parentheses because their precedence can be ambiguous when they are mixed. eslint: no-mixed-operators IMPORTANCE: This improves readability and clarifies the developer's intention. // bad ğŸ‘ const foo = a && b < 0 || c > 0 || d + 1 === 0; // bad ğŸ‘ const bar = a ** b - 5 % d; // bad ğŸ‘ // one may be confused into thinking (a || b) && c if (a || b && c) { return d; } // bad ğŸ‘ const bar = a + b / c * d; // good ğŸ‘ const foo = (a && b < 0) || c > 0 || (d + 1 === 0); // good ğŸ‘ const bar = a ** b - (5 % d); // good ğŸ‘ if (a || (b && c)) { return d; } // good ğŸ‘ const bar = a + (b / c) * d; Copy

title: Multiline Blocksâ€‹
content: Use braces with all multiline blocks. eslint: nonblock-statement-body-position // bad ğŸ‘ if (test) return false; // good ğŸ‘ if (test) return false; // good ğŸ‘ if (test) { return false; } // bad ğŸ‘ function foo() { return false; } // good ğŸ‘ function bar() { return false; } Copy

title: Brace Styleâ€‹
content: If you're using multiline blocks with if and else, put else on the same line. as your if block's closing brace. eslint: brace-style // bad ğŸ‘ if (test) { thing1(); thing2(); } else { thing3(); } // good ğŸ‘ if (test) { thing1(); thing2(); } else { thing3(); } Copy

title: No Else Returnâ€‹
content: If an if block always executes a return statement, the subsequent else block is unnecessary. A return in an else if block following an if block that contains a return can be separated into multiple if blocks. eslint: no-else-return // bad ğŸ‘ function foo() { if (x) { return x; } else { return y; } } // bad ğŸ‘ function cats() { if (x) { return x; } else if (y) { return y; } } // bad ğŸ‘ function dogs() { if (x) { return x; } else { if (y) { return y; } } } // good ğŸ‘ function foo() { if (x) { return x; } return y; } // good ğŸ‘ function cats() { if (x) { return x; } if (y) { return y; } } // good ğŸ‘ function dogs(x) { if (x) { if (z) { return y; } } else { return z; } } Copy

title: New Line Conditionâ€‹
content: In case your control statement (if, while etc.) gets too long or exceeds the maximum line length, each (grouped) condition could be put into a new line. The logical operator should begin the line. IMPORTANCE: This also improves readability by making it easier to visually follow complex logic. // bad ğŸ‘ if ((foo === 123 || bar === 'abc') && doesItLookGoodWhenItBecomesThatLong() && isThisReallyHappening()) { thing1(); } // bad ğŸ‘ if (foo === 123 && bar === 'abc') { thing1(); } // bad ğŸ‘ if (foo === 123 && bar === 'abc') { thing1(); } // bad ğŸ‘ if ( foo === 123 && bar === 'abc' ) { thing1(); } // good ğŸ‘ if ( foo === 123 && bar === 'abc' ) { thing1(); } // good ğŸ‘ if ( (foo === 123 || bar === 'abc') && doesItLookGoodWhenItBecomesThatLong() && isThisReallyHappening() ) { thing1(); } // good ğŸ‘ if (foo === 123 && bar === 'abc') { thing1(); } Copy

title: Selection Operatorsâ€‹
content: Don't use selection operators in place of control statements. // bad ğŸ‘ !isRunning && startRunning(); // good ğŸ‘ if (!isRunning) { startRunning(); } Copy

title: Multiline Commentsâ€‹
content: Use /** ... */ for multiline comments. // bad ğŸ‘ // make() returns a new element // based on the passed in tag name // // @param {String} tag // @return {Element} element function make(tag) { // ... return element; } // good ğŸ‘ /** * make() returns a new element * based on the passed-in tag name */ function make(tag) { // ... return element; } Copy

title: Single Line Commentsâ€‹
content: Use // for single line comments. Place single line comments on a newline above the subject of the comment. Put an empty line before the comment unless it's on the first line of a block. // bad ğŸ‘ const active = true; // is current tab // good ğŸ‘ // is current tab const active = true; // bad ğŸ‘ function getType() { console.log('fetching type...'); // set the default type to 'no type' const type = this.type || 'no type'; return type; } // good ğŸ‘ function getType() { console.log('fetching type...'); // set the default type to 'no type' const type = this.type || 'no type'; return type; } // also good function getType() { // set the default type to 'no type' const type = this.type || 'no type'; return type; } Copy

title: Spaced Commentâ€‹
content: Start all comments with a space to make it easier to read. eslint: spaced-comment // bad ğŸ‘ //is current tab const active = true; // good ğŸ‘ // is current tab const active = true; // bad ğŸ‘ /** *make() returns a new element *based on the passed-in tag name */ function make(tag) { // ... return element; } // good ğŸ‘ /** * make() returns a new element * based on the passed-in tag name */ function make(tag) { // ... return element; } Copy

title: FIXME or TODOâ€‹
content: Prefixing your comments with FIXME or TODO helps other developers quickly understand. Use // FIXME: to annotate problems.â€‹ class Calculator extends Abacus { constructor() { super(); // FIXME: shouldn't use a global here total = 0; } } Copy Use // TODO: to annotate solutions to problems.â€‹ class Calculator extends Abacus { constructor() { super(); // TODO: total should be configurable by an options param this.total = 0; } } Copy

title: Leading commas: Nope.â€‹
content: eslint: comma-style // bad ğŸ‘ const story = [ once , upon , aTime ]; // good ğŸ‘ const story = [ once, upon, aTime, ]; // bad ğŸ‘ const hero = { firstName: 'Ada' , lastName: 'Lovelace' , birthYear: 1815 , superPower: 'computers' }; // good ğŸ‘ const hero = { firstName: 'Ada', lastName: 'Lovelace', birthYear: 1815, superPower: 'computers', }; Copy

title: Additional trailing comma: Yup.â€‹
content: eslint: comma-dangle Why? This leads to cleaner git diffs. Also, transpilers like Babel will remove the additional trailing comma in the transpiled code which means you donâ€™t have to worry about the trailing comma problem in legacy browsers. // bad ğŸ‘ - git diff without trailing comma const hero = { firstName: 'Florence', - lastName: 'Nightingale' + lastName: 'Nightingale', + inventorOf: ['coxcomb chart', 'modern nursing'] }; // good ğŸ‘ - git diff with trailing comma const hero = { firstName: 'Florence', lastName: 'Nightingale', + inventorOf: ['coxcomb chart', 'modern nursing'], }; Copy // bad ğŸ‘ const hero = { firstName: 'Dana', lastName: 'Scully' }; const heroes = [ 'Batman', 'Superman' ]; // good ğŸ‘ const hero = { firstName: 'Dana', lastName: 'Scully', }; const heroes = [ 'Batman', 'Superman', ]; // bad ğŸ‘ function createHero( firstName, lastName, inventorOf ) { // does nothing } // good ğŸ‘ function createHero( firstName, lastName, inventorOf, ) { // does nothing } // good ğŸ‘ (note that a comma must not appear after a "rest" element) function createHero( firstName, lastName, inventorOf, ...heroArgs ) { // does nothing } // bad ğŸ‘ createHero( firstName, lastName, inventorOf ); // good ğŸ‘ createHero( firstName, lastName, inventorOf, ); // good ğŸ‘ (note that a comma must not appear after a "rest" element) createHero( firstName, lastName, inventorOf, ...heroArgs ); Copy

title: Yup.â€‹
content: eslint: semi Why? When JavaScript encounters a line break without a semicolon, it uses a set of rules called Automatic Semicolon Insertion to determine whether or not it should regard that line break as the end of a statement, and (as the name implies) place a semicolon into your code before the line break if it thinks so. ASI contains a few eccentric behaviors, though, and your code will break if JavaScript misinterprets your line break. These rules will become more complicated as new features become a part of JavaScript. Explicitly terminating your statements and configuring your linter to catch missing semicolons will help prevent you from encountering issues. // bad ğŸ‘ - raises exception const luke = {} const leia = {} [luke, leia].forEach((jedi) => jedi.father = 'vader') // bad ğŸ‘ - raises exception const reaction = "No! Thatâ€™s impossible!" (async function meanwhileOnTheFalcon() { // handle `leia`, `lando`, `chewie`, `r2`, `c3p0` // ... }()) // bad ğŸ‘ - returns `undefined` instead of the value on the next line - always happens when `return` is on a line by itself because of ASI! function foo() { return 'search your feelings, you know it to be foo' } // good ğŸ‘ const luke = {}; const leia = {}; [luke, leia].forEach((jedi) => { jedi.father = 'vader'; }); // good ğŸ‘ const reaction = "No! Thatâ€™s impossible!"; (async function meanwhileOnTheFalcon() { // handle `leia`, `lando`, `chewie`, `r2`, `c3p0` // ... }()); // good ğŸ‘ function foo() { return 'search your feelings, you know it to be foo'; } Copy

title: Type Coercion at Startâ€‹
content: Perform type coercion at the beginning of the statement.

title: Stringsâ€‹
content: eslint: no-new-wrappers // => this.reviewScore = 9; // bad ğŸ‘ const totalScore = new String(this.reviewScore); // typeof totalScore is "object" not "string" // bad ğŸ‘ const totalScore = this.reviewScore + ''; // invokes this.reviewScore.valueOf() // bad ğŸ‘ const totalScore = this.reviewScore.toString(); // isnâ€™t guaranteed to return a string // good ğŸ‘ const totalScore = String(this.reviewScore); Copy

title: Numbersâ€‹
content: Use Number for type casting and parseInt always with a radix for parsing strings. eslint: radix no-new-wrappers const inputValue = '4'; // bad ğŸ‘ const val = new Number(inputValue); // bad ğŸ‘ const val = +inputValue; // bad ğŸ‘ const val = inputValue >> 0; // bad ğŸ‘ const val = parseInt(inputValue); // good ğŸ‘ const val = Number(inputValue); // good ğŸ‘ const val = parseInt(inputValue, 10); Copy

title: parseIntâ€‹
content: If for whatever reason you are doing something wild and parseInt is your bottleneck and need to use Bitshift for performance reasons, leave a comment explaining why and what youâ€™re doing. // good ğŸ‘ /** * parseInt was the reason my code was slow. * Bitshifting the String to coerce it to a * Number made it a lot faster. */ const val = inputValue >> 0; Copy

title: Bitshift Operationsâ€‹
content: Note: Be careful when using bitshift operations. Numbers are represented as 64-bit values, but bitshift operations always return a 32-bit integer (source). Bitshift can lead to unexpected behavior for integer values larger than 32 bits. Discussion. Largest signed 32-bit Int is 2,147,483,647: 2147483647 >> 0; // => 2147483647 2147483648 >> 0; // => -2147483648 2147483649 >> 0; // => -2147483647 Copy

title: Booleansâ€‹
content: eslint: no-new-wrappers const age = 0; // bad ğŸ‘ const hasAge = new Boolean(age); // good ğŸ‘ const hasAge = Boolean(age); // best const hasAge = !!age; Copy

title: Naming Lengthâ€‹
content: Avoid single letter names. Be descriptive with your naming. eslint: id-length // bad ğŸ‘ function q() { // ... } // good ğŸ‘ function query() { // ... } Copy

title: camelCaseâ€‹
content: Use camelCase when naming objects, functions, and instances. eslint: camelcase // bad ğŸ‘ const OBJEcttsssss = {}; const this_is_my_object = {}; function c() {} // good ğŸ‘ const thisIsMyObject = {}; function thisIsMyFunction() {} Copy camelCase Export Usageâ€‹ Use camelCase when you export-default a function. Your filename should be identical to your functionâ€™s name. function makeStyleGuide() { // ... } export default makeStyleGuide; Copy More camelCase Usageâ€‹ Use camelCase for variables, properties and function names Variables, properties and function names should use camelCase. They should also be descriptive. Single character variables and uncommon abbreviations should generally be avoided. // bad ğŸ‘ var admin_user = db.query('SELECT * FROM users ...'); // good ğŸ‘ var adminUser = db.query('SELECT * FROM users ...'); Copy

title: PascalCaseâ€‹
content: Use PascalCase only when naming constructors or classes. eslint: new-cap // bad ğŸ‘ function user(options) { this.name = options.name; } const bad = new user({ name: 'nope', }); // good ğŸ‘ class User { constructor(options) { this.name = options.name; } } const good = new User({ name: 'yup', }); Copy PascalCase Export Usageâ€‹ Use PascalCase when you export a constructor / class / singleton / function library / bare object. const AirbnbStyleGuide = { es6: { }, }; export default AirbnbStyleGuide; Copy

title: No Underscore Dangleâ€‹
content: Do not use trailing or leading underscores. eslint: no-underscore-dangle Why? JavaScript does not have the concept of privacy in terms of properties or methods. Although a leading underscore is a common convention to mean â€œprivateâ€, in fact, these properties are fully public, and as such, are part of your public API contract. This convention might lead developers to wrongly think that a change wonâ€™t count as breaking, or that tests arenâ€™t needed. tl;dr: if you want something to be â€œprivateâ€, it must not be observably present. // bad ğŸ‘ this.__firstName__ = 'Panda'; this.firstName_ = 'Panda'; this._firstName = 'Panda'; // good ğŸ‘ this.firstName = 'Panda'; // good ğŸ‘ , in environments where WeakMaps are available // see https://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/#test-WeakMap const firstNames = new WeakMap(); firstNames.set(this, 'Panda'); Copy

title: No this Referencesâ€‹
content: Donâ€™t save references to this. Use arrow functions or Function#bind. // bad ğŸ‘ function foo() { const self = this; return function () { console.log(self); }; } // bad ğŸ‘ function foo() { const that = this; return function () { console.log(that); }; } // good ğŸ‘ function foo() { return () => { console.log(this); }; } Copy

title: Filename Export Matchingâ€‹
content: A base filename should exactly match the name of its default export. // file 1 contents class CheckBox { // ... } export default CheckBox; // file 2 contents export default function fortyTwo() { return 42; } // file 3 contents export default function insideDirectory() {} // in some other file // bad ğŸ‘ import CheckBox from './checkBox'; // PascalCase import/export, camelCase filename import FortyTwo from './FortyTwo'; // PascalCase import/filename, camelCase export import InsideDirectory from './InsideDirectory'; // PascalCase import/filename, camelCase export // bad ğŸ‘ import CheckBox from './check_box'; // PascalCase import/export, snake_case filename import forty_two from './forty_two'; // snake_case import/filename, camelCase export import inside_directory from './inside_directory'; // snake_case import, camelCase export import index from './inside_directory/index'; // requiring the index file explicitly import insideDirectory from './insideDirectory/index'; // requiring the index file explicitly // good ğŸ‘ import CheckBox from './CheckBox'; // PascalCase export/import/filename import fortyTwo from './fortyTwo'; // camelCase export/import/filename import insideDirectory from './insideDirectory'; // camelCase export/import/directory name/implicit "index" // ^ supports both insideDirectory.js and insideDirectory/index.js Copy

title: Acronyms and Initialismsâ€‹
content: Acronyms and initialisms should always be all uppercased, or all lowercased. Why? Names are for readability, not to appease a computer algorithm. // bad ğŸ‘ import SmsContainer from './containers/SmsContainer'; // bad ğŸ‘ const HttpRequests = [ // ... ]; // good ğŸ‘ import SMSContainer from './containers/SMSContainer'; // good ğŸ‘ const HTTPRequests = [ // ... ]; // also good const httpRequests = [ // ... ]; // best import TextMessageContainer from './containers/TextMessageContainer'; // best const requests = [ // ... ]; Copy

title: Optional UPPERCASEâ€‹
content: You may optionally uppercase a constant only if it (1) is exported, (2) is a const (it can not be reassigned), and (3) the programmer can trust it (and its nested properties) to never change. Why? This is an additional tool to assist in situations where the programmer would be unsure if a variable might ever change. UPPERCASE_VARIABLES are letting the programmer know that they can trust the variable (and its properties) not to change. What about all const variables? - This is unnecessary, so uppercasing should not be used for constants within a file. It should be used for exported constants however.What about exported objects? - Uppercase at the top level of export (e.g. EXPORTED_OBJECT.key) and maintain that all nested properties do not change. // bad ğŸ‘ const PRIVATE_VARIABLE = 'should not be unnecessarily uppercased within a file'; // bad ğŸ‘ export const THING_TO_BE_CHANGED = 'should obviously not be uppercased'; // bad ğŸ‘ export let REASSIGNABLE_VARIABLE = 'do not use let with uppercase variables'; // --- // allowed but does not supply semantic value export const apiKey = 'SOMEKEY'; // better in most cases export const API_KEY = 'SOMEKEY'; // --- // bad ğŸ‘ - unnecessarily uppercases key while adding no semantic value export const MAPPING = { KEY: 'value' }; // good ğŸ‘ export const MAPPING = { key: 'value' }; Copy Use UPPERCASE for Constantsâ€‹ Constants should be declared as regular variables or static class properties, using all uppercase letters. // bad ğŸ‘ const second = 1 * 1000; function File() { } File.fullPermissions = 0777; // good ğŸ‘ var SECOND = 1 * 1000; function File() { } File.FULL_PERMISSIONS = 0777; Copy

title: Accessor Functionsâ€‹
content: Accessor functions for properties are not required.

title: Getters / Settersâ€‹
content: Do not use JavaScript getters/setters as they cause unexpected side effects and are harder to test, maintain, and reason about. Instead, if you do make accessor functions, use getVal() and setVal('hello'). // bad ğŸ‘ class Dragon { get age() { // ... } set age(value) { // ... } } // good ğŸ‘ class Dragon { getAge() { // ... } setAge(value) { // ... } } Copy

title: boolean Propertyâ€‹
content: If the property/method is a boolean, use isVal() or hasVal(). // bad ğŸ‘ if (!dragon.age()) { return false; } // good ğŸ‘ if (!dragon.hasAge()) { return false; } Copy Itâ€™s okay to create get() and set() functions, but be consistent. class Jedi { constructor(options = {}) { const lightsaber = options.lightsaber || 'blue'; this.set('lightsaber', lightsaber); } set(key, val) { this[key] = val; } get(key) { return this[key]; } } Copy

title: Data Payloadsâ€‹
content: When attaching data payloads to events (whether DOM events or something more proprietary like Backbone events), pass an object literal (also known as a "hash") instead of a raw value. This allows a subsequent contributor to add more data to the event payload without finding and updating every handler for the event. For example, instead of: // bad ğŸ‘ $(this).trigger('listingUpdated', listing.id); // ... $(this).on('listingUpdated', (e, listingID) => { // do something with listingID }); Copy prefer: // good ğŸ‘ $(this).trigger('listingUpdated', { listingID: listing.id }); // ... $(this).on('listingUpdated', (e, data) => { // do something with data.listingID }); Copy

title: jQuery Object Variablesâ€‹
content: Prefix jQuery object variables with a $. // bad ğŸ‘ const sidebar = $('.sidebar'); // good ğŸ‘ const $sidebar = $('.sidebar'); // good ğŸ‘ const $sidebarBtn = $('.sidebar-btn'); Copy

title: Cache jQuery lookups.â€‹
content: // bad ğŸ‘ function setSidebar() { $('.sidebar').hide(); // ... $('.sidebar').css({ 'background-color': 'pink', }); } // good ğŸ‘ function setSidebar() { const $sidebar = $('.sidebar'); $sidebar.hide(); // ... $sidebar.css({ 'background-color': 'pink', }); } Copy

title: DOM Queriesâ€‹
content: For DOM queries use Cascading $('.sidebar ul') or parent > child $('.sidebar > ul'). Performance Testing Link - jsPerf

title: Scoped jQuery Object Queriesâ€‹
content: Use find with scoped jQuery object queries. // bad ğŸ‘ $('ul', '.sidebar').hide(); // bad ğŸ‘ $('.sidebar').find('ul').hide(); // good ğŸ‘ $('.sidebar ul').hide(); // good ğŸ‘ $('.sidebar > ul').hide(); // good ğŸ‘ $sidebar.find('ul').hide(); Copy

title: Number.isNaNâ€‹
content: Use Number.isNaN instead of global isNaN. eslint: no-restricted-globals Why? The global isNaN coerces non-numbers to numbers, returning true for anything that coerces to NaN. If this behavior is desired, make it explicit. // bad ğŸ‘ isNaN('1.2'); // false isNaN('1.2.3'); // true // good ğŸ‘ Number.isNaN('1.2.3'); // false Number.isNaN(Number('1.2.3')); // true Copy

title: Number.isFiniteâ€‹
content: Use Number.isFinite instead of global isFinite. eslint: no-restricted-globals Why? The global isFinite coerces non-numbers to numbers, returning true for anything that coerces to a finite number. If this behavior is desired, make it explicit. // bad ğŸ‘ isFinite('2e3'); // true // good ğŸ‘ Number.isFinite('2e3'); // false Number.isFinite(parseInt('2e3', 10)); // true Copy

title: No, but seriously:â€‹
content: Whichever testing framework you use, you should be writing tests! Strive to write many small pure functions, and minimize where mutations occur.Be cautious about stubs and mocks - they can make your tests more brittle.We primarily use mocha and jest at Airbnb. tape is also used occasionally for small, separate modules.100% test coverage is a good goal to strive for, even if itâ€™s not always practical to reach it.Whenever you fix a bug, write a regression test. A bug fixed without a regression test is almost certainly going to break again in the future.
